div.head: to Hume's History of England
div.p: David Hume: History of England
© Frits van Holthoon, 2000
Published by InteLex Corporation, Charlottesville, Virginia, USA, 2000

Hume's History of England is a new variorum edition edited by Prof. Frits van Holthoon. The base text is the edition of 1778, from which the Liberty Classics edition was created. Page numbers are also from the edition of 1778 (duplicated in the Liberty Classics edition). For a complete discussion of the text, see the introduction by the editor.

div.head: 1. Introduction
div.p: When I decided to start working on a variorum edition of Hume's History of England eight years ago my motives were mixed. I knew that Hume had made substantial revisions to his work and I felt that somebody should do the necessary homework of charting them. Until recently I was unaware that Graeme Slater had undertaken a similar job. His report discusses a number of variants, most of them in volume five, a few in volume six, which I had failed to notice. These I have incorporated in the text. All Hume scholars knew from a letter from Hume to Gilbert Elliot of Minto that Hume thought that the first volume on the Stuarts in its original version had been "corrupted with Whig Rancour" and had corrected this bias in the third edition of this volume which appeared in 1762 (Vc). So there was also the prospect that his revisions would indicate that Hume had substantially altered his views on certain aspects of English history.

We know that Hume took a great interest in revising his History, but a first impression of the results of his labours is disappointing. Except for the revelation of the plot between Charles II and Louis XIV (that later turned out to be the secret treaty of Dover) no startling new facts resulted from Hume's revisionary labour. He did not change his overall view of English history and the general picture emerging from his revisionary labours is that Hume wanted to groom his original story, not to alter it. Yet this "grooming" points to a very important first conclusion which this edition does substantiate. It is of course focussed on the textual variants, but we should keep in mind that the way Hume wrote his History - backwards - implies a revisionary process in itself.

1. What Hume produced in this way was a view of English history which is diametrically opposed to the Whig interpretation of history as it emerged in the late seventeenth and the eighteenth century. Hume refused to adopt a theory of progress in any form, and if eighteenth-century Britain was a more civilized society with better constitutional arrangements that advance was an accident rather than an automatic product of history. Many of Hume's additions to the social history of England illustrate this fact.
There are two exceptions to my general conclusion.

2. Hume did considerably revise his portrait of Charles I, and my suggestion is that he not only wanted to give a more emphatic profile to his view of the struggle between the king and his parliament, but that he also reacted towards the whig rhetoric by rigorously excising the elements of it from his own prose.
3. By his revisions Hume put more emphasis on the need for authority in the subsequent editions which he revised.

The problems with Hume's revisions to his text and with the three conclusions that I derive from the study of them are the context in which we should interpret them. In order to provide this context I shall go over all too familiar ground with familiar quotations to provide this context. First there is the question of the nature of Hume's History. Forbes writes about it: "It is a history of civilization ... and a political history at the same time and the two aspects of the History fuse - the history of civilization bares its teeth in the arena of politics in the first volume Hume published." That fuzzy metaphor serves the purpose of leaving the exact relationship between a history of civilization and political history in the dark, and I am sure that Phillipson is right in arguing that for Hume "the history of civilization must begin and end with politics." However that conclusion is far from evident. Hume was indeed deeply convinced that civilization depends on the rule of law and the functioning of a well-ordered constitutional system, but his own account of constitutional developments in Britain is so casual - it is almost reduced to a single note which he added to the fourth volume in 1762 (see IV, 355) - that it is impossible to draw any general conclusion from his work on how the "political" determined or influenced the rise of civilization. In his essay "Of the Rise and Progress of the Arts and Sciences" Hume observes
That it is impossible for the arts and sciences to arise, at first, among any people unless that people enjoy the blessing of a free government.

But he also wrote, in another essay, that the House of Commons "owed its chief influence and consideration to the encrease of commerce, which threw such a balance of property into the hands of the commons." In his Essays but also in his History Hume left the causal relationship between civilization and politics largely undetermined and the fact that he added many new details on the social history in the course of his revisionary labour does not solve the mystery, but only depends on it.

The second and the third conclusion are controversial, but at least my edition enables the reader to form his own opinion about them. Next to Slater two other scholars, Ernest Mossner and Duncan Forbes, have made a study of Hume's revisions to his History. Both tend to explain away these two conclusions. Mossner does it by arguing that Hume's pro-whig revisions keep the balance with his pro-tory ones, but the few examples he gives of the latter are far from convincing. Forbes discusses a number of Hume's revisions in an appendix to his Hume's Philosophical Politics, but by pointing out that Hume remained critical of Charles I he belittles the impact of Hume's revisions. Mossner and Forbes are generally right in concluding that Hume's view of politics transcends partisanship. My point is that they could have easily made their case accepting that Hume did revise his portrait of Charles and that he did put greater emphasis on the need for authority later in life.

Early in his writing career Hume called himself a "sceptical Whig", but his endorsement of the Protestant succession is not helpful in defining him as a whig. Hume's own definition of the tory and the whig is well-known:

A TORY, therefore, since the revolution, may be defined in a few words, to be a lover of monarchy, though without abandoning liberty; and a partizan of the family of Stuart. As a WHIG may be defined to be a lover of liberty, though without renouncing monarchy; and a friend to the settlement in the PROTESTANT line.

This is a plea for political moderation, hardly a definition. Moderation is Hume's guiding principle, even making divisions among the whigs themselves. John B. Stewart refers to a distinction Hume made in 1747 between political and religious whigs. The political whig, Hume writes, is "a Man of Sense and Moderation, a Lover of Laws and Liberty, whose chief Regard to particular Princes and Families, is founded on a Regard to the publick Good." The religious whigs are utterly despicable. The profile of the political whigs suited many of Hume's Scottish friends and Hume shared their zeal for the modernization of his country, but I wonder whether the definition is sufficiently clear to make Hume himself into a whig.

We cannot blame Hume for providing a definition which does not enable us to make a sharp ideological distinction according to modern political parties for these did not exist. Lewis Namier has explained to us that allegiance to the tories or the whigs is a matter of family allegiance foremost and that these allegiances constitute the crazy quilt of politics in eighteenth-century Britain. According to allegiance Hume belonged to the Scottish modernizing whigs, but he was an outsider in their circles in almost any terms except that he agreed with them on the standards to which a civilized, a "modern", society should comply. Forbes named Hume a "scientific whig", but I am not sure that is a useful term to characterize Hume's political philosophy, because it evokes the vista of progress which is absent from that philosophy. How can the man who wrote that the idea of the original contract as a historical fact is contrary to experience and that almost "all governments, which exist at present ... have been founded originally, either on usurpation or conquest, without any pretence of a fair consent, or voluntary subjection of the people", be a whig? Reading Hume's History those of his contemporaries with pro-whig sympathies would find much proof in it that he was a tory. Did he not accept Brady's point of view that the Magna Charta strengthened baronial privileges and did nothing to define the rights of the people, and did he not agree with Spelman that the constitutional history of England began with the Norman conquest? Perhaps most offensive to any whig was Hume's view that the Tudors established a quasi-absolute kingship (quasi, because the Tudor kings had no standing army to enforce their authority) which raised the expectations of the Stuart dynasty that they could consolidate the royal prerogative. His sympathetic portrait of Charles I did the rest. We should keep in mind that in a time when the American colonists preferred Rapin de Thoyras's Histoire to Hume's History and when in England Hume's History was the only alternative to a whig interpretation of English history and Catherine Macaulay was his easy rival as a historian, Hume's anti-whig interpretation must have been interpreted as a tory production. The sheer weight of whig propaganda can also make us understand why Hume in a note which he introduced in 1770 branded as despicable the writings of Rapin adding to this list (in 1778) Locke, Sidney and Hoadly. These writers had nothing in common except that they were very popular during the 1770's in whig circles. And lastly the fact that Hume, later in life came to emphasize the need for authority seems to vindicate G. Giarrizzo's observation that Hume became more of a tory in the seventies.

However, Hume was no tory and never became one. The man who wrote that passive obedience is at odds with the nature of the British constitution could not be a tory. Hume excised a passage from V, note Q, p.563 explaining that the patriarchal scheme is nonsense. What he left out for tactical reasons undoubtedly represented his real feeling and in religious terms "a sceptical tory" is a contradictio in terminis. Scholars such as Donald Livingston, Frederick Whelan and David Miller have described Hume as a conservative philosopher, firstly because of his scepticism concerning man's capacity for reason and secondly because Hume had a deeply engrained loyalty for the status quo. Miller expresses this view as follows:

I said in my introduction that the fascination of Hume's political thought lies in seeing how a revolutionary philosophy is married to an establishment ideology to yield what is probably the best example we have of a secular and sceptical conservative political theory.

The problem, which this evaluation of Hume's political philosophy contains, is nicely expressed by the paradox in this quotation and the paradox is deepened if we realize that not only did Hume's epistemology have revolutionary implications, but his political philosophy as well. He who wrote that government is founded on opinion set the door wide open to revolution and that was his attitude to the Stuart kings. Legally they may have been right, but politically they were wrong, because public opinion had changed.

The solution of the paradox is, I think, that the term "conservative" is an anachronism. Hume was a defender of the status quo, and so were Catherine Macaulay, and Burke and his adversary Richard Price. They all accepted the society of orders, in which established classes of people have certain privileges and honoured positions. Regarding morality, law, and the nature of civil society they were traditionalists who took certain rules, and forms of behaviour for granted as being "natural". Donald Winch has warned that it is dangerous to a true insight in Adam Smith's economic thought to make him into the champion of the liberal capitalist perspective. The same applies to the view that Hume is a conservative critic of representative democracy. For the same reason I must object to John B. Stewart's attempt to turn Hume into a reforming liberal. Hume believed in religious toleration, political moderation and (within limits) laissez faire, but he pursued no political ends to promote them. Hume is no Macaulay and with due respect to the distinguished author (who among Hume scholars has the best grasp of the interconnection between Hume's History and his Essays), to read Hume's essay "An Idea of a Perfect Commonwealth" as a program for parliamentary reform seems farfetched to me. Almost as an afterthought Hume wrote in this essay:

Though it is more difficult to form a republican government in an extensive country than in a city; there is more facility, when once formed, of preserving it steady and uniform, without tumult and faction.

One might say that Hume took a hard look at the prospect of representative democracy and rejected it as a practical solution for Britain. "This plan", Hume wrote, "of limited monarchy, however corrected, seems still liable to three great inconveniences", the third of which is that "The sword is in the hands of a single person, who will always neglect to discipline the militia, in order to have a pretence for keeping up a standing army." So an extended republic in the case of Britain would lead to a new Cromwell and so this essay - at least the greater part of it - is an indirect defense of the system of mixed government which Hume adhered to in all other political essays. As early as 1741 his "universal axiom in politics" or "scientific" advice had been:
That an hereditary prince, a nobility without vassals, and a people voting by their representatives, form the best MONARCHY, ARISTOCRACY, and DEMOCRACY.

This quotation comes from the essay "That Politics May Be Reduced to a Science" that serves as an introduction to the analysis of the British political system that Hume developed in a number of essays published in 1741. The odd thing is that Hume's universal axiom does not refer to the mixed government as it prevailed in Britain and that he calls simple forms of government the best ones. However, it is the negative conclusion, implied rather than mentioned, that counts. A mixed government does not qualify as the best government, if we mean by "best" stable, for a mixed government is inherently unstable and needs careful monitoring. This is the lesson that Hume develops in his political essays of 1741.

If Hume nevertheless calls the British regimen mixtum "the most perfect government" (II, 525) at the end of his History, it is because he want to emphasize the fact, that the English (and the Scots) in the course of their long history have evolved the political rules that suit their manners and customs best. The lesson of Hume's History is that in the end (only in 1688) mixed government has become the "established" system of government in Britain.

Hume's quotation does not invite us to consider the merits of a parliamentary democracy. We should take his axiom for what it is. In a mixed system the king and peers act on their own and do not have to rely on a mandate from the people, that the Commons represent. It is the emergence of this system which Hume described in his History and which we must use to interpret his revisionary labour and the three conclusions which I have drawn from the study of Hume's revisions.
To keep Hume's revisionary labour firmly in focus I propose to start with the technical issues involved in making this edition and then give a bird's-eye view of the revisions. These issues are:

1. A List of Editions: First of all I will provide a list of the editions that appeared during Hume's life and of the posthumous edition which appeared in 1778. Furthermore I will indicate the editions and the copies of these editions which I have used for my collation.

2. My Policy of Selection: It should be realized that I only offer a selection of variants between editions. The greater part of Hume's revisions concern stylistic changes. For practical reasons I have excluded mere stylistic changes from my edition.
3. Method of Annotation: I will explain how these revisions are registered and how this edition should be used.

4. An Overview of the Revisions: By way of statistics derived from a list of the main revisions (see Appendix III) I will provide an overview of Hume's revisionary labour per volume and per edition. I will add a qualitative classification of the revisions which can serve as an index to the revisions.

5. A Discussion of Hume's Manuscript of the Medieval History: Only the manuscript of Hume's Medieval History has survived. I will give my reasons for including passages which Hume cancelled in the manuscript.
After settling these technical issues I propose to deal with the following questions:
6. Hume on Religion and Style: Hume's view of protestant "enthusiasm" and catholic "superstition". I will also use this section to make a general remark on the stylistic changes Hume made.
7. Hume's Revision of the Portrait of Charles I: What did Hume mean by correcting his "Whig rancour"?
8. Did Hume Become More Conservative: Did Hume emphasize the need for authority in subsequent editions?
Relatively straightforward answers can be given to these questions, but they also lead to three larger themes which constitute the main body of Hume's History. These are:

9. Hume's Study of Authority Within the History: Hume's revisions have little impact on this theme, but Hume's elaboration of it in the Medieval and Tudor volumes provides the context within which to judge the reigns of the Stuarts, particularly that of Charles I.

10. Rapin de Thoyras and Hume's View of Constitutional Development: Constitutional development is the second important theme. I shall confront Hume's view of History with Rapin's to establish the point that Hume's view is the counterpoint of the Whig interpretation of history. At one time Hume described himself as a "sceptical Whig". It is doubtful whether he remained a whig.

11. The Rise of Commercial Society: Hume wrote two histories in one: a political and a social history, but he established a negative relationship between the two. Hume had no theory of the rise of civilization and he uses social history to point out how primitive English manners and techniques were. This way of writing social history is my strongest argument against regarding Hume as a "scientific Whig".

Perhaps I should end this section with an apology. I undertook my work, because I have developed an interest in how a writer creates his message. Hume, as a study of the manuscript of his Medieval history (the only one extant) demonstrates, was a quick writer. Yet he fussed over his text with great care. To register the process of his revisions seems to me a fascinating approach to his creativity, but I realize that this study of his intentions has become old-fashioned. Nowadays the prevailing doctrine seems to be that we should concentrate on the "text" and disregard the author or that, if we want to approach the author, it is to catch him unaware and reveal his many lapses of belief and reason. For those who think likewise I have done my work in vain.

div.head: 3. My Policy of Selection
div.p: Six years ago I started a campaign for a computer-administered collation of those editions which Hume himself prepared and corrected for the press. The project would involve the transmission of about 42.000 pages of print on disks and the financial threshold for this operation turned out to be too high. It was then that I decided to make a variorum edition for my own use by registering those variants in the text which to me appeared to be significant. I worked my way through 17 editions of separate volumes and through 6 editions of complete sets of the History of England, and by a happy coincidence I got into contact with Mark Rooks and his InteLex Corporation, who has scanned the LibertyClassics reprint of the 1778 edition. His scanning made it possible for me to graft my notes on to the text. As this is an edition which--at least in the first instance--will be read from the monitor, I have chosen the method by which variants of first editions are printed in bold in the text of the LibertyClassics reprint. Variants in other editions are registered in endnotes marked with a cross. In this way the reader can instantly compare the variants, and though the text printed out makes for awkward reading, those who are not interested in them will not use this edition anyhow.

Before I start to explain my method of selection and its possibilities and limitations, let me enter a plea for a computerized edition. The number of revisions which can be registered is stupendous as Appendix IV, in which I have tried to register all variants for V, chapter 45, makes clear. It is perhaps not too strong a statement that Hume was obsessed with the details of his text and was tinkering with it each time when a new edition offered him the opportunity of revision. The massive load of all the revisions he made (adding to them the variants as the product of printing) makes it impossible to include them all in a variorum edition: the notes will swamp the text. In the case of such an edition a selection of variants will have to be made anyway. Obviously a computer-based collation is an important help for the making of such a selection, but its product can also be of use in providing a database for revisions of style and spelling. For those interested in fashions of literary style, the lifelong labour of a provincial Scot who was uncommonly sensitive to style, a database of this sort must be a wonderful field of study. The most important consideration however to concentrate on a selection of variants is the sorry fact that registering all variants takes too long and when done by hand will create a defective method of selection, because one will miss too many variants.
I have decided to register Hume's revisions according to the following critera:
1. Most of the revisions which Hume made are stylistic. I have decided not to register these, if they concern a change of word or parts of sentences.
2. I have also ignored spelling variants.

3. I have registered a change of word and part of sentences which altered the meaning of the text or the emphasis within it. A nice example - because of its philosophical implication - is III, 365.30 where we read about "the profound veneration which it [the doctrine of the real presence] impressed on the 〈〈imagination〉〉. Originally Hume had written 〈〈understanding〉〉 (IIIa(1759), 317.9), in the reprint of 1762 (IIIb(1762), 319.9) this became 〈〈mind〉〉 and in the 1770 edition (1770(4), 359.12) Hume reached his final version. Obviously these selections are subjective and often difficult to make, and originally I had decided to leave them out altogether. This, I believe, would have been a pity, because even in my selection the reader gets a good view of Hume's focus on details in the text. The selection which I offer in this edition is itself selected from a broader database which I have made for myself. Sometimes, as in the case of IV p.390 note K (the note on whether Mary Stuart had written the "casket" letters) I have registered all the smaller variants, because the note contains important variants as well; usually I have ignored these smaller variants even if they come together with variants which were selected.

4. I have registered all corrections of facts which Hume made and which I discovered in his text. At III, 41.1 Hume wrote 〈〈near 400.000 pounds sterling of our present money〉〉; in IIIa(1759), 33.8/9 this had been: 〈〈about one hundred and eighty-six thousand two hundred and fifty pounds sterling〉〉; in IIIb(1762), 33.8 this became 〈〈about one hundred and eighty-six pounds sterling〉〉; the final version was reached in 1773(4), 354.31/2. This example at least involves the computation of present day values, most corrections of fact are even more trivial than this one, except for the fact that this type of revisions shows that Hume took great care to get his numbers and sizes right.
5. Then I have registered alterations, excisions and additions which involve a sentence or more. These can be subdivided as follows:
5.1. Large scale excisions made for editorial purposes,
5.2. Important alterations, and
5.3. Excisions and additions.

An important restriction on my selection is my method of collation. First I have checked variants between the modern LibertyClassics reprint of the 1778 edition [I-VI] and the first editions which appeared between 1754 and 1762 [ Ia - VIa]. Then I checked these variants in subsequent editions. Variants which only occur in the intermediate editions may and will have escaped my attention. Most of them will be trivial ones, but it must be admitted that my method of collation has a teleological cast. I feel confident that I have traced all the longer passages. I have made a check in the editions intermediate between the first and the posthumous editions to see whether I have missed important passages; I have found none. It strikes me that Hume very seldomly introduced notes or passages in the text which he later excised. His was a persistent effort to work towards the perfect text. Evidently, Hume was troubled by certain phrasings. We find him changing the text in subsequent editions. The remarkable thing is that we can sometimes discover that he reached his final version in stages. A note which he added in a certain edition did not escape his vigilant eye in a subsequent one as small changes in the texts testify. In short my claim is that my variorum edition contains all the major ( say of 5 sentences or more) additions, excisions or alterations he made since the first editions of his History. Whether this claim is justified, the user of my edition will have to find out for himself. It is the beauty of an electronic edition that he can easily add his finding to his copy of my edition.

My policy of selection, then, has a large subjective element - particularly with the smaller variants - because it is not easy to decide between whether a revision was made merely for stylistic elements or carries a substantive element. So my selection, I am sure, will be criticized, but I have taken the utmost care - by checking and rechecking the entries given - that the information given is correct. I can only hope I will not disappoint the reader's trust.

div.head: 4. Method of Annotation
div.p: The original footnotes of I-VI have been changed into endnotes; they are in bold type. Footnotes in this edition carry editorial information.

The text of Ia-VIa (as alteration or excision) is printed in bold type in the text of I-VI at the appropriate place. Variants in notes since Ia-VIa are printed in endnotes in normal type. Variants in the text of editions subsequent to Ia-VIa are printed in endnotes (in normal type). If no endnote has been attached to a variant the indication is that the revision only took place in 1778(1/8).

Excisions or additions are passages taken out or added in toto. Alterations are rewritten passages. Sometimes a passage is marked as rewritten though Hume not only altered the previous text, but also added or excised words. For convenience's sake the whole passage in such a case has been marked as an alteration to avoid annotating the text with a great number of small additions and excisions. Sometimes the distinction between, excisions and additions on the one hand and alterations on the other is blurred, e.g., when a combination of an excision and an addition should be regarded as an alteration.
I have used the following symbols:

div.head: 5. A Survey of Revisions
div.p: In Appendix III I have listed the most important revisions. These amount to 530 revisions. Table 1 gives an overview of Hume's revisionary labour. In "Hume and the 1763 Edition" I have published a similar table compiled according to slightly different criteria. Many of the revisions mentioned in this survey will be used in my analysis.

row.cell:
Table 1
Hume's Major Revisions in Percentages of the Total Number of Revisions per Edition.

div.p: Table 1 confirms two conclusions drawn in my essay. Since the edition of 1770 Hume spent a great deal of his time in revising his History. The major exception concerns volume Va: 34% of the revisions took place in Vb and adding the revisions undertaken in Vc to it the total amount is 58%. The significance of this exception becomes the greater when we look at table 2:

cell.emph: Hume's Major Revisions in Percentages of the Total Number per Volume

div.p: 42% of all registered revisions were made in the first volume on the Stuarts. Hume wrote to William Strahan on 12 June 1758 that he had sent up the revisions of the second Stuart volume for the second edition (VIb(1759):

The alterations I make on this Volume are not very considerable; those I make on the first Volume are more so, particularly in the reign of James, which requires to be changd in many Places, in order to adjust it to this previous Volume which I am now composing [IIIa(1759) and IVa(1759)], and which is nearly finished.

So writing on the Tudors Hume felt the need to revise his story of James I and Charles I. Hume tells us in a note (Vb(1759), 106 note, see V, 124 note) that he excised certain passages to avoid duplication with passages in the first Stuart volume. The major reasons for revision, however, must have been, first, that he wanted to establish the link between his thesis that the Tudors had introduced an absolute monarchy in England and the expectation of James I and Charles I that they could rule according to this established practice, and second, that he retouched the portrait of Charles I as king and person.
Looking at the list of Appendix III we can divide the revisions in the following categories:
1. Additions Concerning "Enthusiasm" and "Superstition":

Hume excised a number of passages on religion as being offensive, but he also added some. These form part of more general remarks on religion and the relations between church and state. See IV, 249 in which Hume deplores the cruel insults of the puritan preacher accompanying Mary Stuart to the scaffold. A representative example in volume five is V, 73 note in which Hume has a comment on the rigidity of the puritans in parliament as exemplified by their enforcement of the observance of Sunday. There are no examples of these additions in VI.
2. Additions Concerning the Policy of Charles I:

In a next section I shall argue that in detecting this type of corrections we should not cast our net too widely. In this survey of revisions I shall only make the observation that the majority of these revisions are to be found in volume five, but that Hume's view of constitutional development, of the evolution of the political system and of the partners in this system is linked to these revisions, and that if we do not use a restrictive definition of the corrections of his pro-whig views we would find more examples in other volumes. The best example of such a correction is V, 247. Hume added a remark in which he criticized the king for using the ordinary court and not the star-chamber for the exertion of his prerogative. This remark is related to the trial of Hampden for his refusal to pay Shipmoney. At the same time that Hume added this remark he excised certain passages in which he criticized the illegality of Charles' measure. In 1778 Hume criticized the way Charles defended his measure and tried to exert his authority, no longer the measure itself. Hume mentioned in a letter to Sir Gilbert Minto that he introduced a justification of Charles I for levying Tonnage & Poundage with consent of parliament in Vc, 281.1/11. What he actually wrote was that Henry VIII had levied this tax for a very long time without the consent of parliament. "So long had the inaccuracy continued, without being remarked or corrected!"(V, 208)
3. Additions Concerning Constitutional Development:

There is a continuous series of additions on constitutional development. These additions have to do with Hume's thesis about the development of regal power and the position of the Commons, but they also show Hume's genuine non-partisan interest in the subject. Examples are I, 169 on the Witegamot, II, note F p.531 on the first summoning of the Commons, III, note B p.496 on maxims of government and the manners of the time, IV, 355 note note on the stages of constitutional development, in V, note J p.556 Hume converts part of the text to a note in which he sums up the constitutional development of England. At this time, he adds, given now the regular role of parliament in the political system the division of Court versus Country started to appear. This division was inspired by religious differences. VI, 359 note on the pretension of the Commons to appoint its own Speaker.
4. Additions Concerning Social History:

Many of these additions were made at the end of chapters, in the appendices or in long notes (since 1770) at the end of each volume. Examples are I, note A p.489 on the Celtic origin of the Scots and the Irish, II, 72 miscellaneous transactions in the reign of Henry III, III, note C p.469 on the household of the earl of Northumberland, IV note II p.414 on criminal justice under Elizabeth, V, 133: the first sedan chair was used by the duke of Buckingham, and VI, 154: Harvey's practice suffered because of his doctrine of blood circulation.
5. Additions to the Narrative of his History:

The general tendency for Hume was (at least in I-IV) to add passages on social history and to excise parts of the narrative. Nevertheless additions to the narrative occur in all volumes. At I, 329 Hume added a passage on Henry II and Thomas Beckett. At II, note G p.531 he added a criticism of Froissart's story of the burgesses of Calais, at III, 284 on Henry VIII's surprise that he could not distinguish a maid, at IV, note J p.390 on Mary Stuart's complaint about Murray's partiality, at V, 37 on James I's plan of accommodation between Spain and the Netherlands, at VI, 185 note on the zeal of Charles II for popery. This last addition was caused by Hume's discovery in 1763 that Charles and Louis XIV had hatched a plot against the liberties of England which included "altering the national religion" (another addition at VI, 288). Volumes five and six being highly topical carry more of narrative additions which are geared to political events.
6. Excisions Concerning Religion:

He excised a passage at III, note Q p.478 on the suppression of protestantism at its very beginning. In IV there are no examples of this type of excisions. The obvious examples in volume five are V, 10 an V, 32 respectively on the "enthusiasm" of the protestants and the "superstition" of the catholics. In volume six there is an excision of a passage on the cant of the covenanters at VI, 25, but the most intriguing example is VI, 539[note]. Hume had written that criticism of certain religious groups is no proof of irreligion. That note was excised in the edition of 1770.
7. Excisions of Pro-Whig Passages:

A representative example of the many passages which Hume excised in volume V is at V, 272. I am also quoting it because of the even-handedness of Hume's treatment in the original passage. In his final sentence he is arguing that the king could not preserve old claims "without assuming new ones: A principle similar to that which many of his subjects seem to have formed with regard to the liberties of the people." Both parties in the conflict were trying to change the existing political system. It seems a pity that Hume excised this remarkable observation, but the excision was part of his policy to cancel all the passages which could lead to the misunderstanding that he supported the parliamentary party. At VI, 482 he had originally written that the people at times "had with good reason" doubted the legality of the suspending power of the monarch. With this type of excisions Hume shifted the burden of proof to the party which questioned the legality of measures and practices deriving from the royal prerogative.
8. Excisions of Passages Dealing with Constitutional Development:

Perhaps the remark omitted from V, note Q, p.563 that the patriarchal scheme is nonsense and the idea of the original contract contrary to experience can perhaps qualify as such. I also quote it because it demonstrates that excision does not necessarily mean that Hume had changed his mind on the subject. In this case he had written two essays on the subject which he did not suppress. The fact that Hume excised almost no passages on constitutional development indicates that his thought on the subject was a product of the writing and in the wake of it he was adding to his History.
9. Excisions Concerning Social History:

Excised at II, note T p.537 is a remark on the illiterate being more on the level with men of learning today, excised at III, 126 note is the mention of an epidemia of sweating sickness; there is no example in IV of this type of excisions; in V, 141 note Hume excises the observation that formerly soldiers used to be of higher rank. At VI, 159 is an excision on the compensation to the king for the abolition of wardship and purveyance. The yield is very meagre and confirms the impression reached from the additions on social history that it was Hume's interest to add to the social history of England, not omit facts, because on second thought he considered them irrelevant .
10. Excisions of Narrative Parts of his History: There are a great number of these which may be subdivided as follows:
1. Excisions of Passages about the Reign of Elizabeth Occurring in Volume Five:

V, 4 is an example, it concerns a passage on Elizabeth's happy reign. The reason for these excisions, as Hume himself indicated was the subsequent writing of the Tudor volumes in which Hume would write approvingly on this long and happy reign.
2. Excisions of Passages on the History of Scotland:

Most of these occur in III (see III, 302 on Lennox' recall from Scotland to France as an example). In V, 66 Hume omits a dissertation on the difference between highlanders and lowlanders. VI, 324 deals with Lauderdale's mismanagement of Scotland. William Robertson published his History of Scotland in 1759. This publication by his friend and rival may have made him decide to cancel large descriptive passages on the subject.
3. Excisions of Passages on the History of the Dutch Revolt:

The passage excised about theological disputes in the Dutch Republic and the fate of Oldebarnevelt is at V, 4. I cannot think of any specific reason for these excisions; they may be more the result of Hume's general policy of streamlining his narrative.
4. Excisions of Passages Concerning the Italian Campaign of Francis I:

Hume probably took the decision to cancel a number of large passages in volume three, because Robertson had published his History of the Reign of the Emperor Charles V in 1769. Most of the excisions took place in 1773(3/4); see III, 89 about the fortunes in war of the Venetian republic.
5. Excisions of Narrative Parts in General:

At I, 188 the remark was excised on the Kentishmen who capitulated after the battle of Hastings to preserve their privileges. At II, 288 Hume omitted the remark about Sir Hugh Calverly as a leader of banditti. At III, 8 the passage about Henry Tudor going to St. Paul's for celebrating his victory, at V, 47 a long passage on England's misrule of Ireland was omitted. And at VI, 246 a passage was excised on the dishonour to king Charles II that his ambassador Sir William Temple was better trusted by the Dutch than he himself. Why did he excise the long and critical passage on Ireland? I do not know the answer. The greater part of the excisions must have been undertaken by Hume because of a general editorial policy, not because he had changed a mind. It is unlikely, given his cast of mind and political views, that he came to acquire a more favourable opinion on English rule in Ireland. His general editorial policy was to excise anecdotes and "dissertations" which obstructed the flow of the narrative. Some of these "dissertations" were relegated as notes to the back of a volume. Hume also felt free to add passages, usually on social history, when he discussed a reign after the death of a king. He also used the appendices for this purpose.
11. Alterations:

Clearly the passages that Hume took the care to rewrite, concerned issues which intrigued him. I have also registered a number of smaller rewritings, but if we concentrate on these main issues these are as follows:
1. Hume's rewriting of the note on the impostor Perkin at III, note A p.465. The rewriting was done in 1770 and 1773.

2. A string of notes on Mary's guilt in the murder of her husband Darnley and the conspiracy against Elizabeth. These run from IV note H p.389 to IV note N 395. To these should be added IV, note U p.398. IV, note K p.390, on the authenticity of the Casket letters, is an example of a note which has been heavily edited. All the alterations concern small items; the more important passages concern excisions and additions. The note is a graphic display of Hume's preoccupation with the issue of Mary's character. In volume five the main issue of course is Charles I. At V, note GG p. 576 and connected with it an alteration at V, 481 Hume writes and rewrites a vindication of the king's intentions versus the Irish rebels, and in V, note KK p.580 Hume expressly deals with the problem of Charles I's sincerity. The note was first introduced in VIa(1757), and in all subsequent editions Hume tinkered with the text, adding the paradox about the respective reputations of Henry VIII and Charles I only in 1778. In volume six the major revision was caused by Hume's discovery, while in Paris in 1763, that there had existed a major conspiracy between Charles II and Louis XIV (at VI, 286 note). A number of other revisions are connected with this discovery.

So far the survey of 530 revisions. If we think in terms of volumes, there exists a division between the first four volumes and volume five and six. The first four are more oriented towards constitutional and social-economic issues. From table 3 the pattern emerges that V and VI are the more heavily edited volumes with a great number of excisions. As Hume went on writing his History he became more confident of the message he wanted to convey and additions having to do with manners and prices dominate. III is an exception to this tentative conclusion, because therein we count more excisions than additions. This exception has to do with the fact that in this volume Hume did make a number of major cuts which concern Francis I's campaign in Italy and the history of Scotland.

div.p: Why did Hume add certain passages and cancel others? The answer is that he wanted to soften his criticism of Charles I, and to add to the defense of the king's position. He cancelled certain passages which he considered redundant, because of the publication of Robertson's Histories. For a great number of cases no specific reason can be given why he added or excised certain passages, a habit he already started in writing his History as the manuscripts of his Medieval volumes demonstrate. There is however a tenuous link between his additions on social history and his excisions of narrative elements.

As can be seen from table 4 the correlation between the addition of social data and the excision of narrative elements holds up tolerably well for the first three volumes. In IV it is the events around Mary Stuart which spoil the correlation and it breaks down in volumes five and six. In V the tragic story of Charles I induced Hume to make additions as well as excisions, and in VI the intrigues of Charles II made Hume add many stories and anecdotes.
