div.head: 6. A Note on Hume's Manuscript of the Medieval History
div.p: I have collated Ia and IIa with the manuscripts of these volumes present in the National Library of Scotland. Missing from the manuscript are Appendix II and chapters XXI-XXIII. The speed and facility with which Hume wrote is remarkable. The signatures put in the manuscript make it clear that the manuscript was used for the printing of the volumes. It is not a clean copy. Hume crossed out and added whole passages. So probably he did not use a draft while writing the volumes. On 18 December 1759 Hume announced to Millar that he was planning to undertake the "antient English History" (Letters of David Hume, vol.1, 317); chapter II is dated March [1760], chapter XX, the last chapter in the manuscript has the date April [1761]. Printing started in November of 1761.
I have quoted the passages which Hume cancelled in the manuscript at the appropriate places. A study of the manuscript is interesting for three reasons.

1. The passages which Hume rejected are no indication that they were factually wrong or that Hume had changed his mind on the subject. Sometimes Hume was searching for the right formulation and he only reached it at the third attempt. Mostly he must have thought that the information given obstructed the flow of the narrative.

2. Hume also added certain passages to the manuscript. A good example of his method of working is chapter 12 of the manuscript. At first I was nonplussed by the fact that the double capital letters with which Hume marked his inserts (which he would then write down at the end of the chapter) did not occur in alphabetical order. Presumably Hume went through his writing again and wrote some passage on separate sheets (the inserts marked AA to DD or EE). He then checked his manuscript a second time, wrote the inserts FF to HH and marked them in the text. Ultimately he inserted the newly-written passages in alphabetical order at the end of this chapter. Working like this, Hume was still able to present a readable manuscript to the printer. He himself wrote to Andrew Millar: "My manner of composing is slow; and I have great Difficulty to satisfy myself." Some words and sentences (which I did not register) are crossed out, but it is clear that Hume had no writer's block and wrote his History aus einem Guss.

3. Hume's span of composition is short. He thinks in terms of episodes and observations. As a historian he remained an essay writer and this is the reason why he could easily add and excise passages in the manuscript, and later on revise his text, without ruining the general outline.

div.head: 7. A Note on Hume's Stylistic Revisions, and His Treatment of Religion
div.p: The greater part of Hume's revisions concern changes of style. In a discussion of the first collective edition of 1763 I explained that Hume was sensitive to the smallest detail of what he considered correct prose. There are some set patterns in his changes of style and spelling: "labor" becomes "labour" (and "vigor" etc. "vigour"); "betwixt" "between"; "esteemed" "deemed"; "pretext" "pretence"; "requisite" "necessary"; and his same procedure applies to changes in word order, so "enemies and strangers" becomes "strangers and ancient enemies". As I have not recorded these patterns the reader will have to be satisfied with these few examples.

Gibbon wrote: "Mr. Hume told me that in correcting his history he always laboured to reduce superlatives and soften positives." And indeed Hume had a general tendency to eliminate or replace strong adjectives such as 〈〈scandalous〉〉, 〈〈tyrannical〉〉, 〈〈exorbitant〉〉, 〈〈arbitrary〉〉 or 〈〈generous〉〉. Most of the excisions or alterations were undertaken to reach a greater purity of style (and in this sense Hume offers us the important lesson to avoid the over-rhetorical). Sometimes they demonstrate a shift of opinion and certainly this is the case where Hume prefers the stronger to the weaker term. Such an amusing exception concerns Shakespeare. Hume wrote: "If represented as a POET, capable of furnishing a proper entertainment to a refined or intelligent audience, we must abate 〈〈much〉〉{Va(1754), 137.26: 〈〈somewhat〉〉} of this eulogy. Yet though this example shows that Hume had a conventional eighteenth- century taste in poetry his revisions in general show an awareness of finding the right term, of how to correct ellipsis and use the most economical expression for his arguments. Hume is a great stylist and his revisions do not spoil his style, but improve it.

Possibly in 1756 Hume wrote to John Clephane: "I am convinced that whatever I have said of religion should have received some more softenings." So softening was not just a matter of style, but had a substantive edge to it in his remarks on religion. It turned out to be a major operation, involving three procedures: first an excision of words and passages; second an alteration of words; and third a long note defending his position. Hume cancelled a long passage on the puritans in chapter 45 of volume V and an equivalent passage on the catholics in chapter 46. Many of the offensive passages occur in volume V and Hume's letter refers to the process of weeding them out or indeed softening them. Of this second procedure let me quote one of the more offending passages: 〈〈That speculative despotism might lend assistance to practical, and religious tyranny support civil authority〉〉 sermons were preached by Sibthorpe and Manwaring, in favour of a general loan"; became "〈〈That religious prejudices might support civil authority〉〉 sermons ... ." In this case Hume is referring to propaganda coming from the court, and so his softening of this passage may be seen as being part of his anti-whig campaign. However, I do not think it is in this case. Hume felt very strongly about any abuse of religion and it is this feeling which he vented in the first instance. A more straightforward example of his criticism of religious abuse and its subsequent retouching occurs a few pages before the example just given. Discussing the campaign supporting the Huguenots in La Rochelle he originally wrote that "the British were at that time, and till long after 〈〈sunk into the lowest and most odious bigotry〉〉." This became: 〈〈, the most under the influence of that religious spirit, which tends rather to inflame bigotry than increase peace and mutual charity〉〉.

These two examples come from volume V and the softening already took place in 1759. However there are examples of softening expressions and words in the volumes which (in their first editions) followed in 1762. Hume apparently found it hard to resist expressing his abhorrence of any form of fanaticism or bigotry. Nevertheless it became his standard procedure to convert 〈〈fanaticism〉〉 into 〈〈enthusiasm〉〉 and 〈〈superstition〉〉 into neutral terms such as 〈〈ceremony〉〉 or 〈〈religion〉〉 and the long passages in which he explained that 〈〈fanaticism〉〉 was a synonym of 〈〈puritanism〉〉 and 〈〈superstition〉〉 of 〈〈catholicism〉〉 were, as we have seen, eliminated as well. Hume could be very offensive, as when he compared the protestant sects and their clamour for excommunication with the druids who used "like engine of priestly authority". Wisely Hume dropped this remark in Vb(1759).

An unfriendly critic, John Brown, wrote that "a certain historian" "omitted no opportunity ... to disgrace religion" and that he did so to amuse his reading public and make his book sell better. He was told that he was wrong. "This information had a notable effect: for a second volume, as large and instructive as the first, hath appeared; not a smack of irreligion is to be found in it; and an apology for the first concludes the whole." Brown was evidently referring to a long note which appeared in the last chapter of volume VIa, but he was wrong to call it an apology, it rather is a statement of principle. Hume's argument was that calling fanaticism by its name is not a mark of irreligion nor does it warrant the assumption that sects which have been fanatical in the past remain so in the present. The note was taken out again in the 1770 edition, probably because in the meantime Hume had for himself found the just mean between his horror of any form of "enthusiasm" and his way of expressing it. Perhaps this ironic phrase does not do justice to Hume's genuine concern for the feelings of others and we should add that he was not always aware of the impact of his words on the religious.

Yet it is clear that Hume was a partisan and that his disgust with "enthusiasm" was shared by Robertson, the other moderate literati in Scotland and by the leader of the Enlightenment in Europe, Voltaire. It was a disgust which went deep and it was inspired by the fear that fanatical clergymen would again manage to mobilize the mob to perform unspeakable cruelties such as the burning of witches or the persecution of men whose religious views were different. So, being a partisan, Hume also added observations on religion which certainly will not have appeased Dr Brown, though they now contained a philosophical aspect. So he added the remark at III, 436 (addition made in 1778) that those who suffer martyrdom are the first who are willing to inflict it. And at V, 129 he observed that the puritans did not believe in toleration themselves, but they had learned the lesson that the alternative is the bloodshed of religious war. And Hume was a partisan in a more narrow sense. He took an increasingly negative view of the parliamentary leaders. In reporting on Hampden (or Hambden as Hume spelled his name) Hume originally wrote "deservedly" in a passage on the popularity which Hampden acquired "by his spirit and courage". He excised it in 1773. In V, note AA, which he added in 1778 he wanted to clear up a misunderstanding. He explained that he does not blame Hampden's character. The point is that his intentions are good though his actions are bad. However he ends with the worst slur on Hampden's character: his tang of enthusiasm. Hume's revision of the portrait of Fairfax is more subtle but also more insidious. At V, 448 Hume altered a passage, first in 1762 and in its final version in 1773, which turns Fairfax into a bigot. Originally Hume wrote that Fairfax though eminent for courage and humanity was not guided by honour or virtue but by disinterestedness. This became a man who "strongly infected with prejudices or principles, derived from religious and part zeal" was never diverted from these principles by private interest or ambition.

Hume's jaundiced view of the puritans plays a preponderant role in his judgment on the struggle between the king and parliament. Hume is prepared at all times to give James I and Charles I the benefit of the doubt. Very seldomly does he treat the parliamentary party, the Presbyterians, let alone the Independents, as generously.

div.head: 8. Revising the Portrait of Charles I
div.p: In his My Own Life Hume wrote that he did not yield to the "senseless clamour' of the whigs against his History and
... that in above a hundred alterations, which farther study, reading or reflection engaged me to make in the reigns of the two first Stuarts, I have made all of them invariably to the Tory side.

This sentence has caused the discussion to which I referred in my introduction. In order to take part in the discussion we need a clear definition of what "alterations ... to the Tory side" (and by implication "alterations ... against the Whig side") can mean. Sticking close to what Hume wrote in his letters I would suggest the following criteria:
1. Additions or excisions which favour king Charles I.
2. An emphasis on the legality of the use of prerogatives and of the justified expectation by James I and Charles I that their use of them was legal.

3. The conclusion that the parsimony of parliament under the first two Stuarts aggravated the power struggle between king and parliament and justified the royal complaint that he had no means to defend the realm.
Before I start discussing Hume's corrections on his too-whiggish views according to these three criteria I propose first to deal with Hume's allegedly pro-whig views.

There are almost no additions in which Hume adds to his (considerable) criticism of the king's rule. The prosecution of Williams was the most iniquitous measure of the court, he adds.(V, 243) It reads as if it was an exception rather than the rule. Hume added the sentence in 1762 to a story in which the Commons did not prevail against the Lords : "Happily for the nation, they have been successful in almost all their other claims."(V, 89 note) However we are talking here about the relations between Lords and Commons, not between the Commons and the King, and the fact that the Commons in the long run was becoming an equal partner in the English political system had of course Hume's full approval. So we are not reading anything new. Perhaps the most characteristic addition is where Hume writes that Clarendon was the author of most of the remonstrances of the king written in 1642 with an attempt to reconcile the warring parties. Hume had written in note BB p.572 that these were the clearest assertion of mixed government. In note J and W he explains how the fine tuning of such a system is a learning process, and in this addition he makes Clarendon the architect of the system of mixed government which would be the product of the constitution of 1688. It were the royalists of 1642 who invented the system of 1688! As my quoting of notes J and W already reveals, Hume could see both sides in the conflict and more importantly he could see how this conflict would be productive of liberty.
8.1. Hume's changes in his portrait of Charles I as a man and a ruler

As to the man he writes a long note on the sincerity of the king. It is V, note KK p.580. It is to this note - first introduced in VIa(1757) - to which Hume adds a remark on the paradox of the reputations of Henry VIII and Charles I, only in 1778. The way he ends this addition is at the same time characteristic for his own position:

Even at present, an historian, who, prompted by his courageous generosity, should venture, though from the most authentic and undisputed facts, to vindicate the fame of that prince, would be sure to meet with such treatment, as would discourage even the boldest from so dangerous, however splendid an enterprize.

That is precisely what Hume did although he does it by way of excising critical comments. Typical for his method is at V, 544 where he excises (after "The virtuous prince") the passage "tho' perhaps not entirely innocent". The same method is used to take out all qualifications which make measures and sentences "illegal", "precipitant" or "arbitrary". The representative example is the following:

{Va(1754), 163.27/31: [And to what purpose all these mighty stretches of prerogative, which tore and disjointed the whole fabric of the government, and exhausted all the force of his authority? Only to support Buckingham, a very unfit minister during such critical times; and to carry on war with Spain; a war, in every respect, unjust, unnecessary, and not recommended by the least hopes of success.]}

The passage was dropped in 1759 (see at V, 181) as many of this type of qualifications were dropped in the second edition Vb(1759). The term "Whig rancour" must refer to these passages, as becomes clear from a passage which appeared in the original note of VIa(1757) :

I must here take the opportunity to correct a negligence or rash expression, which I have been guilty of in the first volume. In p.156. l.29 instead of these words, "But he was too apt, in imitation of his father, to consider these premises as temporary expedients, which, after the dissolution of the Parliament, he was not any farther to regard." read, "But he was apt, in imitation of his father, to imagine, that the Parliament, when they failed of supplying his necessities, had, on their part freed him from the obligation of a strict performance."
V, note W p.569 was originally part of the text. Hume took out the following passage in Vb(1759):

{Va, 245.32/246.3: [In this digression, I have here thought proper to indulge myself. The philosophy of government, accompanying a narration of its revolutions, may render history more intelligible as well as instructive. And nothing will tend more to abate the acrimony of party-disputes than to show men, that those events which they impute to their adversaries as the deepest crimes, were the natural, if not necessary result of the situation, in which the nation was placed, during any period. We now return to our subject.]}

Why did Hume drop this passage? The reason must be that he had no hope that his History would cure party prejudices. And in a paradoxical way we can say that Hume's search for impartiality made him a partisan. He made no revision in a passage in the same note which sums up his verdict on the house of Stuart:

It was the fate of the house of Stuart to govern England at a period, when the former source of authority was already much diminished, and before the latter began to show in any tolerable abundance. Without a regular and fixed foundation, the throne perpetually tottered; and the prince sat upon it anxiously and precariously. Every expedient, used by James and Charles, in order to support their dignity, we have seen, attended with sensible inconveniences. The majesty of the crown, derived from ancient powers and prerogatives, procured respect; and checked the approaches of insolent intruders: But it begat in the king so high an idea of his own rank and station, as made him incapable of stooping to popular courses, or submitting, in any degree, to the controul of parliament. The alliance with the hierarchy strengthened law by the sanction of religion: But it enraged the puritanical party, and exposed the prince to the attacks of enemies, numerous, violent, and implacable. The memory too of these two kings, from like causes, has been attended, in some degree, with the same infelicity, which pursued them during the whole course of their lives.

These revisions provide proof that Hume did change his judgment on Charles I. The way he did it is remarkable. He excised any passage which could suggest that the whigs were right, legally and morally, in their rhetoric against the king. The revisions have no effect on Hume's critical assessment of Charles as a weak ruler. In fact by creating more understanding for the difficult position the king was in, he makes it clearer than before that the king was incapable of meeting the challenge.
8.2. On the legality of James I's and Charles I's exertion of their prerogatives

In the revisions of his story on the reign of James I Hume emphasized that both the parliament and the king saw a situation in which the king ruled by his prerogatives as the normal and customary one. In the long note V, note P p.561 Hume made the point that it was the common opinion in James' reign that England had an absolute, not a limited monarchy. In 1762 and 1773 he added new illustrations of this opinion. A new spirit of liberty was awakening, but Sir Francis Bacon and Sir Edwin Sandys were ahead of their time when they insisted on the dignity and authority of the Commons. Characteristically, Hume adds that they were wrong in arguing that the Commons had received a better treatment before. (See V, note C p.550) So by his revisions in this part of his story Hume prepared the ground for the struggle between Charles I and his parliament.

The best cases for reporting on Hume's revisionary labour on the problem of the legality of Charles' measures are "tonnage and poundage" and "shipmoney". Hume referred to one of his important additions in his letter to Sir Gilbert Eliot in 1763. He added the following passage in 1762:

[The parliament did not grant the duty of tonnage and poundage to Henry VIII. till the sixth of his reign: Yet this prince, who had not then raised his power to its greatest height, continued, during that whole time, to levy the imposition: The parliament, in their very grant, blame the merchants, who had neglected to make payment to the crown; and though one expression of that bill may seem ambiguous, they employ the plainest terms in calling tonnage and poundage the king's due, even before that duty was conferred on him by parliamentary authority. Four reigns, and above a whole century, had since elapsed; and this revenue had still been levied before it was voted by parliament. So long had the inaccuracy continued, without being remarked or corrected!]

Since 1762 Hume came to insist that given constitutional custom, Charles could expect the continuation of tonnage and poundage during his reign, because that had been the customary practice under the Tudors.

The addition is remarkable, but not exactly new. Hume had originally written that James I and Charles I could expect that they could rule using a broad interpretation of their prerogatives, but their expectations were thwarted by the innovations of parliament. See the alterations he made at V, 40/42, writing about the reign of James I. Rewriting the passages from the first edition in 1754 (substantially in 1762) Hume emphasized that the Tudors could expect to be in the position to alter rates of customs unilaterally. Now "a spirit of liberty" had taken possession of the House, and Parliament began to regulate its views more "by future consequences" and they aspired less "at maintaining the ancient constitution". Originally Hume had written: "The precedents for so dangerous an exercise of power were neither very recent or numerous", because the duties of tonnage and poundage were usually levied by the authority of parliament.
8.3. On the necessity of Charles' levying of Shipmoney

In a complicated set of revisions at V, 247 we get Hume's most sophisticated verdict on the legality of Charles' levying of Shipmoney. The occasion is the trial of Hampden. In 1754 Hume wrote that the imposition "is apparently the most avowed and most dangerous invasion of national privileges". This passage was edited in subsequent editions and then excised in 1778. In the meantime its impact was weakened by two notes. In the first Hume remarked that Elizabeth at the time of the Armada had ordered the harbours to fit out ships, and in the second and longer note Hume argued that the King may have been forced by necessity to impose shipmoney but that he was wrong in using the ordinary courts to enforce it. He should have used the Starchamber as the instrument of his prerogative to demonstrate the extraordinary character of his measure. Here are the relevant excision and addition:
At V, 247 Hume excised the following passage:

{Va(1754), 218.20/28: [In most national debates, tho' the reasons may not be equally balanced, yet are there commonly some plausible topics, which may be pleaded in favor of the weaker side; so complicated are all human affairs, and so uncertain the consequences of every public measure: But it must be confessed, that in the present case, nothing of weight can be thrown into the opposite scale. The imposition of ship-money, is apparently the most avowed and most dangerous invasion of national privileges, not only which Charles was ever guilty of, but which the most arbitrary princes in England, since any liberty had been ascertained to the people, had ever ventured upon.
And added the following one:

[The defenceless condition of the kingdom while unprovided with a navy; the inability of the king, from his established revenues, with the utmost care and frugality, to equip and maintain one; the impossibility of obtaining, on reasonable terms, any voluntary supply from parliament: All these are reasons of state, not topics of law. If these reasons appear to the king so urgent as to dispense with the legal rules of government; let him enforce his edicts, by his court of star-chamber, the proper instrument of irregular and absolute power; not prostitute the character of his judges by a decree, which is not, and cannot possibly be legal. By this means the boundaries, at least, will be kept more distinct between ordinary law and extraordinary exertions of prerogative; and men will know, that the national constitution is only suspended during a present and difficult emergence, but has not undergone a total and fundamental alteration.]

Particularly this addition reveals an important shift in his interpretation of the struggle between king and parliament. Hume brushes away the argument derived from legality and introduces an argument based on necessity. And one can understand how Hume got his reputation as a tory historian. The Starchamber was one of the first institutions which the Long Parliament abolished as a symbol of tyranny.
Why did Hume make them? Several explanations can be given and they probably add up.

1. They can be seen as being part of his campaign to soften his qualifications. So at V, 533 "impious regicides" becomes "regicides". This is not a pro-whig statement, but forms part of Hume's tendency to eliminate strong adjectives.

2. The second explanation is that Hume had started to react against the whig rhetoric which became very strong in his own time. It is a reaction of the same kind which we find in Edmund Burke's Reflections on the Revolution in France (1792), which was written against the dissenting minister Richard Price. Burke was hostile to the claim which makes liberty a natural right, a hostility which can be traced back to his Vindication of Natural Society (1756), an ironic reaction to the upsurge of natural rights rhetoric. Hume himself, as we know, was a critic of the theory behind the rhetoric since his Treatise.

3. There is also the element of a rhetorical ploy in Hume's revisions. By way of his excisions he strengthened his paradox which he added to note KK. By making Charles blameless and innocent he made his story more challenging and tragic. Unquestionably Hume became a partisan, not so much of Charles as of his story about him. A digression about Hume's verdict on Rapin de Thoyras would be too long at this place - I shall compare their histories hereafter - but let it suffice to call Hume's criticism of Rapin's work most unfair. Furthermore, one cannot read his notes GG and KK in volume five without getting the impression that there is an element of sophistry in Hume's arguments for the king's sincerity.

4. More importantly: the function of his revisions was not to put the blame on the parliamentary party, but to make it clear that both parties were struggling to find their correct position in a new and opaque situation. By taking out legalistic considerations, Hume is adding to the psychology of the situation. He had written that government is founded on public opinion. Public opinion was changing under the influence of religious disputes, and parliament had to learn how to behave in a situation of party disputes. Its leaders failed because they provoked civil war, but the king failed because he was incapable of reading the signs of the time. On the basis of past experience he could expect to rule as an absolute king, on the basis of future expectations he should have learnt that he could not. Let us not forget that Hume did not change his verdict that Charles was a weak and imprudent ruler, one who was incapable to meet the challenge of a new situation.
These explanations, however, can only be provisional, because we still have to deal with another question which Hume's revisions confront us with.

div.head: 9. Did Hume become a Conservative?
div.p: Did Hume grow more concerned about the erosion of authority and the - as he saw it - irresponsible calls for freedom towards the end of his life? In the edition of 1770 he changed his criticism of the whigs as follows:

Compositions the most despicable, both for style and matter, have been extolled, and propagated, and read; as if they had equalled the most celebrated remains of antiquity.{VIa(1757), 445.30: [note]} 〈〈And forgetting that a regard to liberty, though a laudable passion, ought commonly to be subordinate to a reverence for established government, the prevailing faction has celebrated only the partizans of the former, who pursued as their object the perfection of civil society, and has extolled them at the expence of their antagonists, who maintained those maxims, that are essential to its very existence.〉〉
Originally he had written:

{VIa(1757), 445.30/34: 〈〈And because the ruling party had obtained an advantage over their antagonists in the philosophical disputes concerning some of their general principles; they thence assumed a right to impose on the public their account of all particular transactions, and to represent the other party as governed entirely by the lowest and most vulgar prejudices.〉〉}

The note on the "compositions the most despicable" he added (in 1770 only mentioning Rapin, but adding Locke, Sidney and Hoadly in 1778) also shows his animus. Add to this the comment in the last essay he wrote, "Of the Origin of Government", published posthumously for the first time in 1777. Hume wrote:

In this sense [that an administration must act by general and equal laws], it must be owned, that liberty is the perfection of civil society; but still authority must be acknowledged essential to its existence: and in those contests, which so often take place between the one and the other, the latter may, on that account, challenge the preference.

If we keep in mind that Hume in his correspondence complained bitterly that the authorities did little to restrain the mob and its agitation for Wilkes, it is clear that Hume grew concerned that authority would not be able to maintain general and equal laws. In volume five of his History he let the royalists in 1640 argue:
Authority, as well as liberty, is requisite to government; and is even requisite to the support of liberty itself, by maintaining the laws, which can alone regulate and protect it.
In his essay "Of the Origin of Government" Hume made the argument of the royalists his own.

So political events late in life had an effect on how he viewed the relationship between liberty and authority. We can understand why many contemporaries came to regard Hume as a tory historian, but he was no tory and did not become one later in life. The revisions only demonstrate that events strengthened his anti-whiggism. The term conservative also does not explain Hume's reaction. He did not become more conservative in the last six years of his life, but he was concerned that the system of mixed government was in danger of being wrecked. There is perhaps some justification for concluding that Hume ceased to be a whig, but he never became a tory and his History bears testimony to the fact that Hume in writing his History transcended both the whig and the tory view of the past. We have seen that already in 1741 he drew the conclusion that a regimen mixtum is the best political system for Britain.

Hume wrote the history of the emergence of this system in England and of the conditions which ensured its efficient operation. That same history had taught him, however, that the system would remain fragile and unstable and that political moderation was constantly needed to keep the balance between the partners in this system of mixed government. Hume was not getting more conservative in 1770, perceptive as he was, he started detecting the first signs that the system of mixed government was coming under strain because of ideological and social changes.
So far I have tried to show whether Hume changed certain views on English history and I have maintained that:
1. Hume made a great number of anti-whig revisions.
2. Near the end of his life he was concerned about the erosion of authority.

This revisionary labour does not mean that Hume became a tory, but that his political philosophy transcends the whig and tory political positions. In order to grasp the full significance of this conclusion I propose now to reverse my procedure and use the context of Hume's History to illustrate this conclusion. I will do so by discussing three themes which determine the structure of his History:
1. A study of authority.
2. A constitutional development which in the end approached the optimal mix of liberty and authority.
3. The rise of "commercial society".

div.head: 10. A Study of Authority
div.p: Thomas à Becket - "the first man of English descent" to rise "to any considerable station" - who became Henry II's most trusted adviser was, on the king's order, elected archbishop of Canterbury. No sooner was he installed "in this high dignity, which rendered him for life the second person in the kingdom, with some pretensions of aspiring to be the first, then he totally altered his demeanor and conduct." He "affected" the behaviour of a saint and awaited the first occasion for picking a quarrel with Henry on the independence of the Church from royal authority. On his murder Hume's comment was:

This was the tragical end of Thomas à Becket, a prelate of the most lofty, intrepid, and inflexible spirit, who was able to cover, to the world and probably to himself, the enterprizes of pride and ambition, under the disguise of sanctity and of zeal for the interests of religion.

This (in English historiography) unusually hostile view of the saint was the product of Hume's deeply felt aversion against the possibility of the church dominating the state. What made Thomas à Becket an especially hated figure was his claim that the Church should be independent and clerical authority supreme. If successful this would have made "superstition" the measure of all things. Hume was Machiavellian in his view that the state should control the church and that the point of having a state church was to be able to control religion.

England's rulers had to cope with violent and ambitious men - not the least of Elizabeth's virtues as a queen was her ability to attract able and wise advisers as her ministers - and the first and foremost of their qualities should be whether they could control these men (usually men, sometimes women). It is not difficult to discover Hume's model of the perfect king. Hume wrote about Alfred the Great:

He seems indeed to be the model of that perfect character, which, under the denomination of a sage or wise man, philosophers have been fond of delineating, rather as a fiction of their imagination, than in hopes of ever seeing it really existing.... He knew how to reconcile the most enterprizing spirit with the coolest moderation; the most obstinate perseverance with the easiest flexibility; the most severe justice with the gentlest lenity; the greatest vigour in commanding with the most perfect affability of deportment; the highest capacity and inclination for science, with the most shining talents for action. His civil and his military virtues are almost equally the objects of our admiration; excepting only, that the former, being more rare among princes, as well as more useful, seem chiefly to challenge our applause.
This was Hume's portrait of the ideal ruler. The worst example of English kings was king John:

The character of this prince is nothing but a complication of vices, equally mean and odious; ruinous to himself, and destructive to his people.... His European dominions, when they devolved to him by the death of his brother, were more extensive than have ever, since his time, been ruled by any English monarch: But he first lost by his misconduct the flourishing provinces in France, the ancient patrimony of his family: He subjected his kingdom to a shameful vassalage under the see of Rome; He saw the prerogatives of his crown diminished by law, and still more reduced by faction.

In the good king virtues and capabilities blend, in the bad king weakness and vices prevail. From the description of Alfred's admirable qualities we can easily derive the qualifications a ruler should fulfil.
1. The ruler should be a vigorous military commander, able to defend the realm. Hume had only faint praise for a great conqueror like Edward III:

And indeed, from the unfortunate state of human nature, it will commonly happen, that a sovereign of genius, like Edward, who usually finds everything easy in his domestic government, will turn himself towards military enterprizes, where alone he meets with opposition, and where he has full exercise for his industry and capacity.

Hume disapproved of offensive wars. He even went as far as to conclude that an English victory in the Hundred Years war would have been a misfortune for England as well as France. He acknowledged Cromwell's capacities as a military commander, but thought his war against the Dutch unfortunate. And Elizabeth, who organized the national defense against Spain, got high marks as a leader of men in a defensive war.
2. The ruler should be an efficient administrator like William the Conqueror, or Henry II. Of the Tudors Henry VII and Elizabeth came in for praise.

3. But more important was the ruler in his role as lawgiver. The virtues of the legislator had been an object of admiration since ancient history, but in mentioning Alfred, Edward the Confessor (though in other respects regarded by Hume as a weak and superstitious ruler), Henry II and Edward I as important lawgivers Hume added a new aspect to the portrait of the legislator. In classical (or biblical) times the legislator had presented a complete code to his fellow citizens, but Hume stressed the contributions of the lawgivers to the establisment of the rule of law in England. For this reason we probably should not include William the Conqueror in Hume's list, for though this Norman king introduced feudal law in England that very same system of law divided the nation into Norman rulers and English subjects, and it was only with the gradual abolition of feudal law that the nation became united under the rule of one law. I don't think that we should include later rulers such as Henry VIII under the great legislators. Of course he had a profound influence on the development of the English constitution, but it was less his personal achievement than a combination of forces such as the Reformation, the modern notion of kingship and empire, and the rise of commercial society which effected this. Charles I could also be said to have had a great effect on constitutional developments if only by resistance.

4. Alfred combined humanity with authority but of the two virtues the latter was the more important. His perfect match of these two qualities makes his example less instructive, because most kings do not possess it and so we need other criteria to determine the qualities of their reign.
Here is the paradox to which I have referred:

What a paradox in human affairs, that Henry VIII. should have been almost adored in his life-time and his memory be respected: While Charles I. should, by the same people, at no greater distance than a century, have been led to a public and ignominious execution, and his name be ever after pursued by falsehood and by obloquy!
Henry VIII earned the reputation of being a great prince "while his tyranny and barbarity exclude him from the character of a good one." But Hume adds that this king had an important asset:
This prince not only acquired the regard of his subjects; but never was the object of their hatred: He seems even in some degree to have possessed, to the last, their love and affection.

Henry had as we would call it today, charisma. He had the backing of public opinion in whatever he did, and this backing more than anything else was the cornerstone of his authority, capricious and tyrannical though he was. Charles I in Hume's description provides a perfect contrast to Henry:

He deserves the epithet of a good, rather than of a great man; and was more fitted to rule in a regular established government, than either to give way to the encroachments of a popular assembly, or finally to subdue their pretensions.

And Hume pursues his reflections by remarking that Charles was a monarch born out of time. I have already quoted the words that had he "been born an absolute prince, his humanity and good sense had rendered his reign happy". "Had the limitations on prerogative been in his time, quite fixed and certain, his integrity had made him regard, as sacred, the boundaries of the constitution." Unhappily his political prudence was not sufficient to cope with unprecedented situations. He was a good man whom, the people came to regard as a tyrant. The point Hume is driving at is clear and could come straight out of Machiavelli's Prince. As long as a monarch is able to woo public opinion and remain popular he can behave as an arbitrary despot and no virtuous prince can save his authority trying to challenge public opinion. Government is founded on public opinion, and any person with executive authority should realize this prime rule of the art of government. We can also formulate this principle in Hobbesian terms: a ruler has authority as long as he has authority and no prerogative can help him if he loses it.

It is not that Hume applauded public opinion as a necessary dynamic principle, as the prelude to revolution; he rather feared it. In "Of the Coalition of Parties", an essay published for the first time in 1758, which contains his most fundamental criticism of the whig or "popular party" (i.e. the party representing public opinion) he wrote:
The true rule of government is the present established practice of the age. That has most authority, because it is recent: It is also best known, for the same reason.

The key-words here are "that has most authority". Hume had in mind that custom and justice will keep moving society in its well-ordered channels as long (as he did put it in "Of the Origin of Government") as justice is supported by obedience. However, who will ensure this obedience? "In reality, there is not a more terrible event, than a total dissolution of government", and given man's factious nature and his willingness temporarily to forget his "real and permanent interests" the risk of such a dissolution is a permanent possibility. Authority then is the prime asset of a ruler and the reason why Elizabeth is the real heroine of Hume's History is that she had it.

It is her capacity to rule men and master situations which determines his judgment. His comparison of Elizabeth and Mary, queen of Scots, in this respect is instructive. Mary's charm and "great accomplishments both of body and mind, natural as well as acquired" were praised. But she was no match for Elizabeth: Mary "was always inferior in personal conduct and discretion, as well as in power, to her illustrious rival." Hume's verdict of Elizabeth's personal virtues is not very flattering:

Had this princess been born in a private station, she would not have been very amiable: But her absolute authority, at the same time that it gave an uncontroling swing to her violent passions, enabled her to compensate her infirmities by many great and signal virtues.

What tips the balance is her public conduct as monarch. Read Hume's famous analysis of Mary's guilt (both of the murder of Darnley and of complicity in the plot against Elizabeth) which Hume elaborated in subsequent editions. It is a brilliant treatment of largely circumstantial evidence which is based on the premiss that Mary had a capricious character and was unfit to rule.

Such is Hume's Machiavellian judgment of character. He does not condone private vices, and virtues do get praised, but he considers them only to be relevant if they influence a public outcome of decisions which are unfortunate to public order or the good of the nation. Criticizing Charles I's lack of good sense in relation to the Scots he remarks:
Men's view of things are the result of their understanding alone: Their conduct is regulated by their understanding, their temper, and their passions.

And how small seems to be the role of reason in the conduct of his political actors. Yet this is what he writes of Elizabeth: we may not admire her as a woman, because she lacked some "softness of disposition". "But the true method of estimating her merit, is to lay aside all these considerations, and consider her merely as a rational being, placed in authority, and entrusted with the government of mankind." He sums up his verdict of her as follows:

Her vigour, her constancy, her magnanimity, her penetration, vigilance, address, are allowed to merit the highest praises, and appear not to have been surpassed by any person that ever filled a throne ... By the force of her mind, she controuled all her more active and stronger qualities, and prevented them from running into excess: Her heroism was exempt from temerity, her frugality from avarice, her friendship from partiality, her active temper from turbulency and a vain ambition: She guarded not herself with equal care or equal success from lesser infirmities; the rivalship of beauty, the desire of admiration, the jealousy of love, and the sallies of anger.

As a monarch she was a rational being, because she undertook to govern public affairs with caution and moderation. Hume, as I noted earlier, repeatedly pointed out that Elizabeth ruled as an absolute monarch but that she never undertook an action against the "established principles of the times", and that her understanding of what they were, made her a great queen.

It is of some interest to consider Hume's qualification of Elizabeth as "a rational being". What Reason meant to Hume is the subject of an ongoing debate, fortunately since Annette Baier's book on Hume's Treatise we know what to make of that enigmatic sentence from book two: "Reason is and ought only to be the slave of the passions." Reason can only function properly when inspired by imagination and that mental capacity primarily is a product of our feelings. If we survey Hume's judgment of Elizabeth's character it is hard to avoid the conclusion that in writing history he had forgotten his epistemological doctrine. Elizabeth was a rational ruler in spite of her passions and particularly in the judgment of character Hume reveals his Enlightenment bias: the measure of man is to have moderate views and having his passions controlled by reason. This bias is the negative side of his eminent qualities as an historian. Hume tells his story extremely well. If his History sometimes misses the quality of making us see the interconnectedness of things, it is because the political scientist in Hume is constantly interfering with analytical questions. In the case of Elizabeth he is interested in what her rule produces, not in what motivated Elizabeth in her personal life. And the first question he is asking considering that outcome is how she did maintain her authority.

If we approach his History as a study of authority Hume's verdict on Charles I, indeed on all the Stuart kings is damning. And if we look at the revisions from this angle they add to the criticism and do not exonerate the Stuarts. James I and Charles I were incapable of rising to the challenge of the new claims of parliament. These were innovations according to Hume, but they were nevertheless the political reality the first two Stuart kings had to cope with. They failed where Charles II and James II squandered the good will of the people. It is of interest to quote his judgment on Cromwell:

The domestic administration of Cromwel, though it discovers great abilities, was conducted without any plan either of liberty or arbitrary power: Perhaps, his difficult situation admitted of neither. His foreign enterprizes, though full of intrepidity, were pernicious to national interest, and seem more the result of impetuous fury or narrow prejudices, than of cool foresight and deliberation.

I could not resist quoting the last sentence in this quotation, though it is not relevant to my argument, because it shows that Hume was a consistent critic of imperialistic adventures. However, what is pertinent to the study of authority is the fact that even an exceptionably able ruler, given the social forces in England, is condemned to rule in a vacuum if he cannot operate within a system of mixed government. The Royal executive had to be reintroduced in the system before it could work again. That was the lesson of the Restoration, as it was of 1688 that the authority of the king should remain firmly established considering the liberty of his people.

The maintenance of authority for Hume was an important subject. Forbes points out that the "Vulgar Whigs" rejected French absolutism. Hoadly preached on the unhappiness of absolute monarchy. Hume did not share their distaste for the French monarchy. It ensured a civilized way of life, because it was able to maintain the rule of law. Hume evidently regarded the French monarchy as stable and sound; that opinion says little for his prophetic powers, but then prophets are rare.

div.head: 11. Rapin de Thoyras and Hume's View of English Constitutional Development
div.p: Why did Hume brand Rapin as a whig? Possibly he became irritated when he observed that his Histoire was a classic work to the True and Honest Whigs at home and the American colonists abroad. Linking his name to those of Sidney, Hoadly and Locke can hardly have been the product of deep reflection. However, what about Rapin, the historian?

Sieur Paul de Rapin de Thoyras was a huguenot who at the time of the revocation of the Edict of Nantes made his way into England. Trained as a lawyer at the famous protestant academy of Saumur he was not able to find work in England and going to the Dutch republic he joined the company of his nephew and made a military career which he ended as a captain in the service of William, the stadtholder-king with whom he returned to England in 1688. After his military career he became governor for the young duke of Portland. Then leaving that service he returned to the Hague in 1699, married and retired to the German town of Wesel where he spent the rest of his life writing his Histoire d'Angleterre which was in the process of being published when he died in 1725.

Voltaire said of it: "L'Angleterre lui fut longtemps redevable de la seule bonne histoire complète qu'on eût d'un pays où l'on écrivait que par esprit de part". Translated immediately into English by Tyndal (English edition: 1725/31) it was regarded as the authoritive account of English history, both on the continent and in Britain, until Hume's History appeared on the scene. Rapin, indeed, protested his impartiality in his treatment of issues and personalities. In a focal passage interlaced with the events of 1641 related to the quarrel between Charles I and the Long Parliament, Rapin explains his own system. The king and his party had concluded that they had to repair the grievances which were shared by peers and commons and that the majorities in both houses of parliament, not interested in a revolution of the government of state and church, were willing to return to what they regarded as the natural state of affairs. However the presbyterians who wanted this revolution nurtured the distrust of the others against the king, and the king was imprudent enough to be caught in the trap set by his presbyterian enemies. In this way and by fomenting false rumours the presbyterians gained the upper hand in parliament and prevented a compromise. So in 1641 the presbyterians were convinced they could change the system of government and introduce their version of religion, but it was the king who had created their opportunity. Rapin is very clear in stating that Charles I had the fixed purpose to enlarge the royal prerogatives - "de porter l'autorité Royale beaucoup plus loin que le Roi son Père ou aucun de ses Prédécesseurs n'avoient fait" - and that he was singularly inept in carrying out his design. So the king had started the innovations in the existing system of government and in the crisis which he created the presbyterians took over his design of changing the system of government to suit their own purposes.
Originally Hume was favourably impressed by Rapin's achievement, but as soon as he started to write his own history his opinion became hostile. Hume wrote in 1753 to John Clephane:

You know that there is no post of honour more vacant than that of History. Style, judgement, impartiality, care - everything is wanting to our historians; and even Rapin, during this latter period, is extremily deficient.

Six months later he is much more harsh: "Rapin, whom I had an esteem for, is totally despicable". And in his essay "Of the Protestant Succession" he wrote in the editions between 1752 and 1768 that Rapin, "suitable to his usual malignity and partiality" had judged James I and Charles I with too much severity. In the two editions of 1752 he had added the qualification "the most judicious of historians". We can understand that the two judgements do not match and that is possibly the reason for the omission of the positive one. After 1768 he dropped Rapin's name altogether. We have already quoted Hume's qualification of Rapin's work in the edition of 1770 of his History as a composition "most despicable". Does the quality of Rapin's Histoire warrant Hume's abusive language?

The answer must be in the negative. Rapin wrote a history (illustrated with a great number of official documents and interlaced with ecclesiastical history) which deserves its reputation as a serious work. What must have agitated Hume was Rapin's verdict that the king had the fixed purpose from the beginning of his reign to enlarge his authority at the expense - as Rapin saw it - of the existing political system which demanded co-operation between king and parliament. Hume disagreed, but Rapin's interpretation is at least a possible one. We have already seen that Hume complained that, according to Rapin, Charles could do no good and that he accused him of insincerity and tricks. Was Hume entirely successful in clearing the king's name? Why this passionate hostility? There are two answers to this question. The direct one is that Hume was more of a partisan than he wanted us to believe and the more speculative answer is that the perspectives Hume and Rapin used in writing their histories were dramatically different. Rapin started writing his history from the beginning gradually unfolding his plot, Hume, working his way backwards, came to the conclusion that there is no unfolding of a plot.

According to Rapin the Anglo-Saxons had introduced the system of government which ever since had prevailed in England. It was, Rapin writes, a mixture of monarchical, aristocratic and democratic elements. This view is an interesting variation on the whig point of view, as formulated by William Petyt, that the Ancient Constitution guaranteed the rights of the people and that these rights were the source of royal authority. The English model had been a mixed government ab origine according to Rapin. It goes too far to make Rapin the inventor of the Whig Interpretion of History which we usually associate with nineteenth century historians such as Macaulay and Stubbs and according to whom English constitutional history is the improvement of an original model, but certain elements of this interpretation are already offered by Rapin. In a Dissertation sur les Whigs et les Torys which was originally published in 1717 Rapin maintains that the constitutional equilibrium between king and parliament was reached under Henry V. It is true that Henry VIII ruled as a absolute prince, but he did so with the consent of parliament and Charles I had not learned this essential lesson. Henry VIII also performed the service to the nation in that he gave the Reformation its English shape. Like Hume Rapin was an advocate of moderation, but for him it was political and religious moderation:
Le seul moyen pour y rétablir le calme et la tranquillité seroit, de laisser le Gouvernment sur l'ancien pied, et l'Eglise, dans l'état où la Réformation l'a mise.

It is a point of view which allows for an adaptation of the original model to time and circumstances, and though Rapin's view of English history lacks the idea of positive development it is more dynamic than that of the advocates of the Ancient Constitution.

And Hume? Interestingly enough Hume subscribed to the notion - derived from Tacitus' description of the German tribes - that the government of the Germans "was always extremely free". That remark is made at the beginning of Appendix I on "The Anglo-Saxon Government and Manners" in which Hume then explains that the Saxon government in Britain was an aristocracy which left little power to the kings. Royal power was established with the Norman conquest and the introduction of the feudal regime. And only a long time after that conquest did representatives of the towns and freeholders of land manage to claim a say in political decision making. A long time after, in an addition, made in Appendix II on "The Feudal and Anglo-Norman Government and Manners", which is characteristic for his view, Hume writes:

[If in the long period of 200 years, which elapsed between the Conquest and the latter end of Henry III. and which abounded in factions, revolutions, and convulsions of all kinds, the house of commons never performed one single legislative act, so considerable as to be once mentioned by any of the numerous historians of that age, they must have been totally insignificant: And in that case, what reason can be assigned for their ever being assembled? Can it be supposed, that men of so little weight or importance possessed a negative voice against the king and the barons? Every page of the subsequent histories discovers their existence; though these histories are not written with greater accuracy than the preceding ones, and indeed scarcely equal them in that particular.]{Ia(1762), 409.23: [ ]}

Hume's view is that there is no continuity between so-called Saxon liberty and the idea of the representation of the people. That idea became a reality after the Norman conquest. And furthermore, the Magna Charta far from being a confirmation of Saxon constitutional ideas, did not introduce the Commons as a representative institution. Hume made many revisions to make a further point: even after the Commons emerged as a representative body it maintained a very imperfect idea of its liberties. Almost casually as a note Hume summed up his idea of constitutional development. Let me give it in the context in which is was added:

But Elizabeth only supported the prerogatives, transmitted to her by her predecessors: She believed that her subjects were entitled to no more liberty than their ancestors had enjoyed: She found that they entirely acquiesced in her arbitrary administration: And it was not natural for her to find fault with a form of government, by which she herself was invested with such unlimited authority. In the particular exertions of power, the question ought never to be forgotten, What is best? But in the general distribution of power among the several members of a constitution, there can seldom be admitted any other question, than 〈〈What is established?〉〉{IVa(1759), 716.25: 〈〈What is usual?〉〉}

Few examples occur of princes, who have willingly resigned their power: None of those who have, without struggle and reluctance, allowed it to be extorted from them. If any other rule than 〈〈established〉〉{IVa(1759), 716.27:〈〈ancient〉〉}practice be followed, factions and dissentions must multiply without end: And though many constitutions, and none more than the British, have been improved even by violent innovations, the praise, bestowed on those patriots, to whom the nation has been indebted for its privileges, ought to be given with some reserve, and surely without the least rancour against those who adhered to the ancient constitution.{IVa(1759), 716.33: [note]}
Then follows the note I referred to:

By the ancient constitution, is here meant that which prevailed before the settlement of our present plan of liberty. There was a more ancient constitution, where, though the people had perhaps less liberty than under the Tudors, yet the king had also less authority: The power of the barons was a great check upon him, and exercised great tyranny over them. But there was still a more ancient constitution, viz. that before the signing of the charters, when neither the people nor the barons had any regular privileges; and the power of the government, during the reign of an able prince, was almost wholly in the king. The English constitution, like all others, has been in a state of continual fluctuation.

"Our present plan of liberty" is not the product of a gradual and conscious improvement, either in practices or in political consciousness. It is much more the product of blind forces which have produced it more as an accident than as a triumph of human intelligence. Even the puritans, Hume explains in an important note in volume five, have been no conscious promoters of civil liberty. When that spirit of civil liberty revived "by means of its religious associate, from which it reaped more advantage than honour, it secretly enlarged its dominion over the greater part of the kingdom." The paradox of the puritans as the agent for the promotion of liberty is that they had a very imperfect notion of liberty themselves.
Because Hume wrote his History backwards his final conclusion occurs at the end of volume two. The final sentence reads:

An acquaintance with the ancient periods of their government is chiefly useful by instructing them to cherish their present constitution, from a comparison or contrast with the condition of those distant times. And it is also curious, by shewing them the remote, and commonly faint and disfigured originals of the most finished and most noble institutions, and by instructing them in the great mixture of accident, which commonly concurs with a small ingredient of wisdom and foresight, in erecting the complicated fabric of the most perfect government.

According to Hume, the English by trial and error have blundered into "the most perfect government" and the chief lesson of history is that the past cannot explain the present. Clearly Rapin provoked Hume's wrath, because of his negative verdict on Charles I, but that wrath may have deepened, because Rapin presented the most sophisticated version available at the time of a whig view which presaged that of the nineteenth century whig historians. Hume thought that this idea of the progress of civil liberty was a dangerous myth. There is no constitutional development in the true sense that the historian could explain how one phase is the necessary outcome of a previous one. Hume's lesson from history was that "the most perfect government" remained an unstable one which had to be kept in order by political moderation which gave each partner in the system of mixed government its due.

div.head: 12. The Rise of Commercial Society
div.p: As I wrote before, Hume had no theory of progress. This lack creates the greatest problem for interpreting his History, because it is clear that Hume heralded the expansion of domestic and international trade which had given rise to a society in which commerce is a great civilizing influence, just as he applauded mixed government as the best outcome of English history. How did Englishmen get to this civilized state? Hume refused to answer this question. In the set of essays which was published as Political Discourses in 1752 and which established his reputation as writer he came closest to an answer. Under a free government, Hume writes, the rise of trade leads to a dispersion of wealth:

In this circumstance [the dispersion of wealth] consists the great advantage of ENGLAND above any nation at present in the world ... And if there were no more to endear to them that free government under which they live, this alone were sufficient. The poverty of the common people is a natural, if not infallible effect of absolute monarchy; though I doubt, whether it be always true, on the other hand, that their riches are an infallible result of liberty.

The reservation made at the end is typical of Hume's sceptical bent, but other essays show that he held a positive view of the conditions which the English model of government created for material and cultural progress. He argued "That it is impossible for the arts and sciences to arise, at first, among any people unless that people enjoy the blessing of a free government" And though a monarchy may be more conducive to the polishing and refinement of the arts ("and a republic is most favourable to the growth of the sciences"), the arts and sciences "require a fresh soil" and where else to find it, but under the conditions created by a free government?

So, his Essays could make us expect that we will find a theory of progress in his History, but the fact is that we do not. Hume did not employ Turgot's four stages theory according to which a people passes to the stage of a commercial society through the stages of hunting, herding, and farming.Hume did not introduce any notion of economic determinism in the sense that the English acquired a free government because of the expansion of trade. On the contrary Hume introduced many additions on the subject of social history in which he demonstrated the primitive conditions in which the English lived and how rudimentary their notions of doing business were. A perfect example is III, note C p.472; Hume explained how uncomfortable the life was of the powerful baron in the realm of Henry VII, the earl of Northumberland. He used the household book of the Percy family to write this note. He got a letter from the Rev. Thomas Percy, who was hurt by Hume's negative account of his ancestors. Hume wrote back an obliging and tactful letter in which he wrote to Percy:

My notion is, that the uncultivated Nations are not only inferior to civiliz'd in Government, civil, military, and ecclesiastical; but also in Morals; and that their whole manner of Life is disagreeable and uneligible to the last Degree. I hope it will give no Offence (and whether it do or not, I must say it) if I declare my Opinion, that the English, till near the beginning of the last Century, are very much to be regarded as an uncultivated Nation; and that even When good Queen Elizabeth sat on the Throne, there was very little good Roast Beef in it, and no Liberty at all.

This quotation sums up Hume's notion of progress. England has become "a cultivated nation", but Hume will not speculate on how England became civilized, let alone that he applies a theory of development to English history. His History - its social as well as its political history - has the function of debunking any laudatio temporis acti and to warn Englishmen that their achievements are recent and can easily get lost, because they depend on the rule of law and a stable political system.

We have discussed the indications that towards the end of his life Hume grew nervous about what he saw as an erosion of authority. Perhaps we should conclude that Hume became nervous about a wider range of problems. Hume's ideas about the public debt were known since he published his essay "Of Public Credit" in 1752. A large public debt could subvert the political order, because it made it possible for the executive to bypass parliament. It also subverted the social order, because it made it possible for "stockjobbers" and monopolists to dominate the economy at the expense of the landowning class. It was the same message which Adam Smith conveyed in The Wealth of Nations. In 1773 Hume added a note at IV, 373 note on the disastrous effect of the public debt. It is the only revision I can find where Hume made a direct reference to a contemporary political issue. The note itself contains nothing new, but the fact that Hume now traced the emergence of the public debt to the rise of commercial activities in England may be a further indication of the seriousness of Hume's concern.

By manipulating the public debt the king and his ministers could corrupt parliament and circumvent its controlling power, because the executive is less dependent on parliamentary subsidies. At the same time as Hume showed his concern for the erosion of authority he saw the risk which a large public debt created to the independent position of parliament, or liberty as it was then commonly understood. The answer to the question which I raised at the beginning of this section is that Hume believed that the progress which had been achieved contained the risk of disrupting the social order and the political system. Hume above all put his faith in an equilibrium between social classes and a balance of political powers which reflects this equilibrium and that is why the regimen mixtum is the ultimate achievement of English history. And if the system of mixed government was to continue functioning in the proper way the executive should be able to maintain the rule of law while parliament should, on the one hand, control the executive, and on the other, ensure enough latitude to Englishmen as partners in a commercial society in which each social class would have its natural place. Phillipson is right with his characterization of Hume's History. It is a political history in the first place, because Hume exhorts his countrymen that the regimen mixtum is the best way for maintaining a form of civilized life in Britain. It is also an exercise in political science, because English history demonstrates that a delicate art of government is needed to keep the balance between authority and liberty. Commercial society with its civilized standards is an end to history in the sense that it marks the alternative between chaos and a measured form of progress which will not upset the political and social status quo. A model of mixed government is the best recipe for a commercial society to advance in this orderly fashion.

From a nineteenth-century perspective Hume was of course a conservative, because he rejected, by implication, the soundness of popular sovereignty as a political doctrine. On the other hand Stewart is right in insisting that the civilized values Hume believed in would have made him a liberal and even a reform-minded liberal, if he had lived in the nineteenth century, but Hume's "liberalism" depended on his implicit beliefs and his explicit ideas that these values can only flourish under the political and social status quo. Hume's History concluded with the end of history. Of course, there would be historical events to relate in the future, but these could only be interpreted in a positive way, if they conformed to the precept which Hume had derived from English history: there can be no order in English society except when the regimen mixtum is operating. For those who use the concept today it may be cause for reflection that Hume's recipe became outdated in the year of his death with the American Declaration of Independence.

div.head: 13. Conclusion
div.p: How did the revisions Hume made to his History effect his view of English history and what are the political implications of his revisionary labour?

1. My main conclusion is that the function of the revisions was to groom Hume's message. That conclusion is complicated by the fact Hume developed his message while writing. So the textual revisions should be understood within the context of this writing process.

2. On two subjects we can say that Hume changed his message. He first of all retouched his portrait of Charles I, and, secondly since the 1770 edition he did put more stress on the need for authority. Both revisionary operations were undertaken to counteract the whig rhetoric of his own time which made the people the fountain of authority. The operations did not make Hume a tory. A man who comments on the doctrine of "passive obedience" as being absurd cannot be called a tory. Neither do I think it is useful to conclude that Hume became more conservative. That notion is anachronistic.

3. Whether Hume remained a "sceptical Whig" or was a "scientific Whig" is a matter of definition. I prefer the formulation that Hume transcended the whig-tory controversy and that the outcome of both the completion of his History and the textual revisions was that Hume made the doctrine of mixed government the beginning and end of his political views.

4. The striking aspect of his additions to social history is the total absence of a theory of social development. These additions have the function of supporting Hume's view that the past can offer only one lesson for the future: we should concentrate on the smooth operation of the regimen mixtum which England is fortunate to have.

This was my interpretation of Hume's revisionary labour. However this edition is first of all a research tool which readers can use independently of my interpretation. It is not a critical edition. To make such an edition further study is required of
1. Hume's sources;
2. hidden references and quotations in the text; and the
3. reliability of Hume's account in the light of modern historiography.
If possible I will pursue my study with the study of Hume's sources which promises the greater yield for the study of Hume's work.
F.L.van Holthoon, February 1999

Slater's work is a welcome addition to my own. Slater's main conclusions that 1. Hume softened his language when discussing religious issues, and 2. that his revisions produced a more favourable portrait of Charles I are in agreement with my own. Slater failed to notice the second edition of the Medieval volumes also published in 1762 (Ib and IIb). For this reason, perhaps, he has attached too much weight to the 1763 edition, which as I have demonstrated is the only edition which Hume did not revise. He writes ( Slater, 136 n.2) that "pace" Mossner and Forbes "the editions of 1763 and 1767 are not identical". The 1767 (octavo) edition is a title-edition made with the sheets of the 1763 edition. So the two editions are identical, except for the twenty odd pages of cancels which were first printed separately in 1766 and inserted in the 1767 (octavo) edition. Slater quoting from the cancels can prove his point. See my "Hume and the 1763 Edition of His History of England", Hume Studies XXIII 1997, 133-153. It was not always easy to identify Slater's references. In doing so I have corrected a number of inaccuracies.

Hume admitted as much himself. In his essay "Of the Parties of Great Britain" he added a note at the end in 1758 (see D. Hume, Essays, Moral, Political and Literary, E. F. Miller ed., (Indianapolis 1987: Liberty Classics) 72, note 11) in which he wrote that he retracted some of the opinions delivered in these essays in his History. In 1758 he had only published the first editions on the Stuarts: Va(1754) and VIa(1757). VIa(1757) already involved at least one revision of the text in Va(1754), but it is clear that Hume referred to Va(1754) in the first place when he wrote about retraction. The History was a project for revision from the onset.

What he retracted from the essay "Of the Parties of Great Britain" is reasonably clear. The subject of his retraction is mentioned as "public transactions in the last century"., so these must deal with transactions of statements concerning the Civil War and possibly the Glorious Revolution. Now, Hume writes (Essays, 67-68) about "many noble privileges, which, ... , were universally deemed to belong to them [subjects of the king] as their birth-right." And on pages 69 and 71 Hume refers to the "arbitrary designs" of the king, whom he calls "An ambitious, or rather a misguided, prince" on page 68. These were the kind of expressions which Hume later condemned as Whig rhetoric. However, Hume mentions "Essays" in the plural so he is probably referring to all the essays which preceded "Of the Parties of Great Britain" in the collection of 1758. These are the essays published between 1741 and 1748. The essays of 1741 and 1742 contain no references to public transactions in the last century, but "Of the Original Contract" and "Of Passive Obedience", published in 1748, do. In the former essay Hume wrote "Those [violent innovations] in the reign of Charles I. were derived from faction and fanaticism". (Essays, 477) Addressing his accusation of factionalism and fanaticism to both parties in the conflict Hume may have felt that he was making too large a concession to the Whigs. It is the only time Hume blamed the private character of Charles I. In his History and the revisions since the first edition - as can be read in the text of this Preface - Hume created the image of Charles as a virtuous man who undeservedly acquired the reputation of a tyrant.

In "Of Passive Obedience" (Essays, 492) Hume wrote this about Charles I and James II: "These were harmless, if not, in their private character, good men; but mistaking the nature of our constitution, and engrossing the whole legislative power, it became necessary to oppose them." In his History Hume made it clear that "the nature of the constitution" was unclear and that this unclarity was a cause of the conflict. In his 1758 essay "Of the Coalition of Parties" - so after the publication of Va(1754) and VIa(1757) - he gave his new version of the constitutionality of Charles I's behaviour. He wrote (Essays, 497) that "The House of Tudor, and after them that of Stuart, exercised no prerogatives, but what had been claimed and exercised by the Plantagenets. Not a single branch of their authority can be said to be an innovation." Here Hume went one step further than in his first edition of the History. There he wrote that both parties were guilty of innovations, now - by implication - he puts the blame on the Parliamentary party. In the editions between 1758 and 1770 he attached a note to the sequel of the quoted passage (Essays, 644) in which he tells that he advances the opinion that the Tudors had more authority then their immediate predecessors "with some diffidence". In 1759 with the publication of the volumes on the Tudors the diffidence was already dispelled. His argument in these two volumes became that the Tudors instituted a quasi-absolutist regime. Again Hume's argument shifted. The Tudors were the innovators and the first two Stuart kings could expect to follow in their footsteps. His instruction to drop the note in the edition which appeared a year after his death, was long overdue.

The only full scale work on Hume is by V.G. Wexler, David Hume and the History of England, (Philadelphia 1979: American Philosophical Society). It is an indifferent work. N. Phillipson, Hume, (London 1989: Weidenfeld and Nicolson) is charming but somewhat parochial. Hume was more than a member of Scottish polite society. Of the essays D. Forbes' "Introduction" to his reprint of Va(1754): The History of Great Britain, The Reign of James I and Charles I, (Harmondsworth 1970: Penguin), is still the best. D. Wootton's essay "David Hume, the Historian", D.F. Norton ed., The Cambridge Companion to Hume, (Cambridge 1993: Cambridge University Press) is unsatisfactory. There are two collections worth mentioning in which philosophers and political scientists approach Hume's History: D.F. Norton and R. Popkin eds, David Hume, Philosophical Historian, (Indianapolis 1965) and N. Capaldi and D.W. Livingston eds, Liberty in Hume's History of England, (Dordrecht 1990). J.B. Black, The Art of History, a Study of Four Great Historians in the Eighteenth Century, (London 1926) needs a successor.
