I do not want to start an - inevitably - long discussion on Hume's "artificial virtues" as he defined them in his Treatise of Human Nature, book III, but will limit myself by pointing out that Hume maintained that in the course of human development they came to operate as natural virtues. Hume and Burke as opponents of the natural rights theory were close to its traditionalist implications. For the distinction between traditionalism and conservatism see K. D. Hume, ibidem. There is an addition to this passage which Hume added in 1752 and excised in 1770 in which he called a standing army a "moral distemper" of which "it must at last inevitably perish". He also pointed out that Sweden seemed to be able to combine a limited monarchy with a standing army and militia.

I am putting "scientific" between quotation marks, because it seems to me that Hume uses "science" not in the restricted sense of modern English as "natural science". It defines any form of systematic discourse as in the German "Wissenschaft" or the Dutch "wetenschap".
"That Politics May Be Reduced to a Science", Essays, 18

I have used William B. Todd's nomenclature for the quarto volumes which appeared as separate editions. His classification is based on William Strahan's Ledgers which are part of the collection of manuscripts in the British Library. (Ms. 48800 Add) See W.B. Todd, "David Hume, a Preliminary Bibliography", W.B. Todd ed., Hume and the Enlightenment, Essays Presented to Ernest Campbell Mossner, (Edinburg/Austin 1974) 189-205;
Other copies are in BL, BOD, TxU, K, P, KB C, Csj, Dt, DUc, MRu, Ob, WNs, CaOHM, CaOTU, CoU, CsMH, CSt, DGW, MnU, MH-H, PPL, PU, TxHR, ViWG, UBG. See for a key to these abbreviations Appendix I.
Copies are in the following libraries: BL, TxU, BOD, NLS, BMp, C, Csj, DUc, MRu, Ob, WNs, CaOHM, CaOTU, CaOWEU, CaQMM, CCFB, CLUS/F, CsMH, Cst, MnU, MH-H, NcGU, NjP, PPL, TxHR, CoU
IIIa and IVa have a continuous pagination. The manuscript was sent off to Strahan in August 1758 (Letters of David Hume, 258)
Other copies are listed in the following libraries: BL, NLS, BOD, NLA, TxU, GOT, CaOHM, CaOTU, CoU, MH-H, NjP, TxHR, BN, UBG.

In 1754 Hume wrote to Andrew Millar on 12 April 1755 "that if the first volume bore a little of a Tory aspect, the second wou'd probably be as grateful to the opposite Party." And: "Upon the whole, I wish the two Volumes had been publishd together." (Letters of David Hume, vol.1, 217 and 218) and on 3 May 1755 he wrote to William Strahan that the discouragement caused by the reception of volume one had retarded his work on the second one (ibidem, 221). After the publication of this second volume Hume wrote William Mure "that I think my first Volume a great deal better than the second: The subject admitted of more Eloquence, and of greater Nicety of Reasoning, and more acute Distinctions." The writing of the second volume also suffered from my disgust with the reception of the first one (ibidem, February 1757, 242).

Todd mentions another copy in the New York Public Library. This however is a copy of the first edition. The 1767 quarto title edition also includes a copy of Ib and IIb. See hereafter. Hume was very quick with his revisions of Ia and IIa. On 15 March 1762 he writes to Millar "I am running over both the antient History & the Tudors, and shall send them up by the Waggon as soon as they are corrected." (Letters of David Hume, vol.1, 352) The printing of this second edition took place in December 1762.
Other copies of IIIb and IVb available in the Royal Library at The Hague. This edition has a separate pagination of the two Tudor volumes.

Copies available in NN and MH-H. Millar told Hume that he had printed a new set of the Tudors. (Letters of David Hume, vol.1, 443 note 2, letter dated 24 April 1764) Hume responded by expressing his regret that he had not known about this reprint, because he had "a copy very fully corrected, with a few Alterations, which ought to have follow'd". (Letters of David Hume, vol.1, letter dated 23 May 1764, 443/444) An inspection shows that the copy is similar to IIIb and IVb. The copy I have seen in The Houghton Library at Harvard has the misprint 1744 on the title page of IIIb. So does the copy in the set recently bought by the University Library of Groningen (see shelfmark KWC 876). No notice of this reprint appears in Strahan's ledgers, so apparently Millar used another printer. Hume's revisions got lost in the post (Letters of David Hume, to Strahan, October 1766, 97).

Copies available in other libraries: NN, NLA, BN, MRu, WNs, MBNEH, MH-H, PPL, TxHR, NSPM, CLU, KB. Todd mentions a cancel with the signature 3D3 in the NLA-copy (Todd, Preliminary Bibliography, 190). Hume wrote to Strahan on 12 June 1758 that he had sent up the revisions for "the second volume of my History" (going to be VIb). These revisions "are not very considerable, but those for the first volume are, "particularly in the reign of James" in order to adjust it to the volumes on the Tudors he is writing at present. (Letters of David Hume, vol.1 , 281. And he hopes that Millar will be also willing to reprint the first volume on the Stuarts (going to be Vb). A month later he reports to Strahan that he has reached an agreement with Millar on a reprint of Va. He adds that as the Tudors will be published under the title the History of England and the Stuart volumes as the History of Great Britain, both sets will be regarded as different works. Evidently Hume did not consider the writing the Medieval volumes as well. When, in 1763 his complete work was published as a set in 8 volumes its main title became The History of England, and the History of Great Britain was added, awkwardly at the end of volume 5 beginning with the reign of James I. In the editions of 1770, 1773, and 1778 it opened volume 6. The subtitle is absent in the LibertyClassic reprint.

Copies 0f Vc and VIc available in other libraries: TxU, NLS, ViWC. As indicated in the title the separate quarto volumes came to be regarded as a set in 1762. The volumes now were numbered chronologically and the Medieval volumes became volumes I and II in the set, the Tudor volumes III and IV and the Stuart volumes, V and VI. The set is still a combination of separate volumes. Chapters except in the Medieval volumes only number per reign. Furthermore there is no uniform set of volumes. The set in the Royal Library of The Hague (originally belonging to the library of the Stadtholder) is made up of Ia, IIa, IIIb, IVb, Vb and VIb. The set which belonged to Lord Grenville (now in the British Library) is made up of first editions. The university library of Groningen recently bought a set which is made up as follows: Ia, IIa, IIIc, IVc, Vd, VIc/VId. The set of NLA (CAM 440) contains Ib, IIb, IIIb, IVb, Vc and VIc (and not Ib, IIb, IIIc, IVc, Vd and VIc: Todd, 196) See also the set of the 1767 quarto edition. Hume reports to Millar 15 March 1762 that he is glad a new edition of the Stuarts will be published (Vc & VIc) and that he is correcting the Tudors and the Medieval volumes (which would become Ib & IIb, IIIb & IVb). He advises Millar to use his revised copies to print the octavo edition Millar was planning for next year. (Letters of David Hume, vol.1, 352)

There is a copy of the first volume of the Stuarts in the library of the university of Chicago which is identical to Vc, but which shows the clear evidence that it was separately printed and which bears the date of 1763 on its title page. There are a number of printing differences. So Vc, 12.21 has "mainained", this was corrected in Vd, 12.21 as "maintained".

In Strahan's ledgers a copy of the second volume of the Stuarts, comparable to Vd, is mentioned for 1763. (see BL ms. 48800 Add, 142b March 1763). Indeed there were two printings of this volume, but in 1762! A comparison of the set of the National Library of Australia and the set recently bought by the university library of Groningen shows variants, if only very minor ones and which were caused by the printing process, not by Hume's hand. So there are two "families" of printing, almost identical, in 1762.(see my "Hume and the 1763 Edition of His History of England", 152 note 52)

Copies available in the following libraries: BL, Dt, DBL,NLS,LEu, cAAEU, CSt, ViWC, BOD, NSPM. This was the first edition in which the separate volumes were printed as a set and in which the chapters were numbered consecutively. The number of chapter 38 was accidentally dropped. The mistake was repaired by having two chapters 40. As I explained in my essay "Hume and the Edition of 1763" Hume came to detest this edition. It was the only edition which escaped his revisionary labour. Nevertheless I have included it in my collation, because I wanted to check the imput of the printer in the creation of variants. That imput is negligible. In My essay "Hume and the Edition of 1763" I discuss the reasons for Hume's dislike of this edition.
There also exist separate sets of the octavo version. One is bound together with an Dublin edition of 1772; see Bodleian Library, Shelfmark Vet. A5, e.2983-2990

Copies in other libraries: BL, UBL, NLS, BOD, OMc, MoLiWJ, CaNBFU, MH, NNC. This is a title edition made with the sheets of the 1763 edition. Hume had a row with Millar, because Millar in his "rapacity" had printed too many sheets to Hume's taste. The cancels of 1766 were a welcome opportunity to make a new "edition". The printing of the title pages for the octavo as well as the quarto edition is registered in Strahan's ledgers (48800 ADD, 151b).

This is a title edition made up of Ib, IIb, IIIb, IVb, Vc, and VIc for which Strahan printed the title pages. It contains the important cancels printed separately in 1766. Copies in other libraries: GU, CyC. I have not checked whether these sets contain the same volumes as in MH-H.

Copies in other libraries: BL, Dt, NLS, CaOTU, CtY-BR, MiU, MH, TxU, WaPS, GOT. From vol.VI the title of the set becomes: The History of Great Britain From the Accession of James I. to the Revolution of 1688. By David Hume, Esq. vol. VI-VIII. A New Edition, Corrected. London: Printed for T. Cadell, (Successor to A. Millar) in the Strand. 1770

This is the most beautiful edition which appeared during Hume's life. This set has the curiosity that it contains Hume's "My Own Life" as well as Adam Smith's letter to William Strahan. Hume dated his autobiography 18 April 1776 and Smith's letter was dated 9 November 1776. Strahan printed an octavo separate edition so that proprietors of earlier editions could keep it with their sets. My Own Life appeared for the first time in the Scotch Magazine for January 1777. Afterwards it appeared in the first volume of the posthumous edition of 1778. Apparently Strahan also printed a quarto version, and in the few cases where the 1770 edition had not been bound yet it was included. John Price mentions 12 other copies.(See his Catalogue of Scottish Books, 1708-1875, December 1993)

Hume reported to Millar on 19 Oct. 1767 that he was using all his leisure time for correcting his History. (Letters of David Hume, vol.2, 170). To Strahan he writes on 5 June 1770 "I wish Millar had saved the Expence of this Magnificent Quarto Edition". Nevertheless he tells Strahan that he already has made revisions for a next edition! (ibidem, vol.2, 225) Then two weeks later follows the outburst to the same correspondent that since the publication of the Quarto the 1763 edition "must be totally discredited" (ibidem, vol.2, 228, 21 June 1770).

Copies in libraries: BL, CaNSHD, NLS, BOD, MnM. Before I acquired my own set I worked with a microfilm of copies in the British Library, shelfmark 597d, vols 1-8. A number of page numberings are defective in vol.5 and 6 of the copy of the British Library. In my copy only one misprint remains.

In March 1771 Hume writes to Strahan "This is the last time I shall probably take the pains of correcting that work". (Letters of David Hume, vol.2, 239) However, after the 1773 edition was published, writing to Strahan again he hopes to get "Information some time beforehand" if a new edition should be planned. (ibidem, vol.2, 278, 24 March 1773) Hume the revisionist was insatiable.
Other copies in the following libraries: BL, UBA, PBM, C, Dt, NLS, BOD, WIUS, CaNSH-HMS, Ct-BR.
See Appendix V for a tree of Dublin editions.

In fact more pages have to be transferred to digital files, because in a definitive edition copies within an edition have to be compared. Todd mentions a number of cancels in different copies of one edition (Todd, 200 note 10) . So possibly there exist copies of Ia(1762) and IIa(1762) with title pages inserted which give them the appearance of Ib(1762) and IIb(1762). These should be examined.
For my method of annotation see infra in the text.

See Appendix IV. In this appendix I have tried to annotate V, chapter 45 to the smallest detail working this time from the first edition in 1754 to the posthumous edition of 1778. The result confirms my impression that Hume himself had a teleological cast of revising. There are almost no intermediate revisions, and as the only ones concern spelling they may have been caused by the printer rather than by Hume. For other observations see Appendix IV.
As some of Slater's variants prove it is easier to miss alterations of this type than either excisions or additions.
"Hume and the Edition of 1763", Hume Studies, XXIII(1997), 149 Appendix II.
New Letters of David Hume, 12 March 1763, 70; Hume mentions p.180. This must be a mistake.

Slater (Slater, 150) suggests that Hume excised his favourable comments on the Dutch as part of his anti-whig campaign. Given that Hume never changed his favourable view of the Dutch - reading his correspondence or Essays - it is more likely that the excisions were undertaken for the reason given in the text.
See National Library of Scotland, Ms. 23160.

As they are crossed out with thick vertical strokes they, sometimes, are not easy to read. I have used the numbering per chapter (mostly) which presumably was entered by the compositor, because it is easiest in using the microfilm of the manuscript. The passages are reproduced by permission of the Royal Society of Edinburgh from the RSE Hume Bequest, held on deposit at the National Library of Scotland.

**There is a cancel at chapter 19, 21. It occurs in an insert DD which runs from II, 379 to the end of chapter 19: The first commission of array ...to II, 381 , end of chapter ... more absolute princes.:**//And may even affirm, that in a Country, where the Sovereign has so wretched an income, if he asserts no extraordinary Prerogative, he will possess no Authority and must scarcely be able to execute the Laws.//**This excision is a good example of the fact that Hume did not change his opinions. This remark which in later editions of V led to additions in the same vein emphasizing the fact that James I and Charles I sometimes had to use their prerogatives, was excised from the manuscript, because it was irrelevant for the narrative.**cf. IIa(1762), 322.8
Letters of David Hume, vol.1, 12 April 1755, 108
"Hume and the 1763 Edition of his History of England", 133-153
Quoted by E. C. Mossner in his "Was Hume a Tory Historian?", 230.
See V, 151; the final version was reached in 1773
J.Y.T. Greig, The Letters of David Hume, vol.1, 237
These are reprinted by W.B. Todd in his Introduction, I, xiv-xviii. See V, 10 and 32; The excisions were already made in the second edition Vb(1759).
V, 177; the revision was made in Vb(1759)
For a not exhaustive list of examples: I, 216, III, 415, 419, V, 68, 80, 107, 441/442, 443, 494, VI, 25, 40, 59.

The Letters of David Hume, vol.1, letter 132 20-5-1757 to Andrew Millar, note 3 John Brown, An Estimate of the Manners and Principles of the Times, (1757) 57. Hume reproached Millar for the fact that Brown evidently had read a letter of Hume to Millar in which Hume had argued against the argument that irreligion explained the lacklustre sale of his first volume, and, on the contrary, would promote the sale of his book.

Slater (Slater, 148) creates the misleading impression that the draft of this note at V, 482 reveals an addition to the printed text. However, Hume completely rewrote - apart from two passages - the draft. See E.C. Mossner, The Life of David Hume, (Oxford 1980: Clarendon Press) 307. I have printed the text of the draft after the note. The reader can notice that the construction of the argument in the draft runs parallel to the published note, but that the draft is much more aggressive in tone. If we keep in mind that the draft was meant to be the preface to VIa(1757) it is clear that at the time of writing VIa Hume was still in no mood to soften his language on religious issues. Next to Brown Mossner mentions John Witherspoon (309), Daniel MacQueen (306), and William Rose (305) as Hume's critics of his treatment of religion in the History. See also Slater 140-145. Slater adds Flexman to the list of critics.

Rapin de Thoyras prints the remonstrance and declaration of the two chambers of parliament and the king's answer. His analysis is that the documents confirmed the positions of the conflicting parties, see Rapin de Thoyras, Histoire d'Angleterre, vol.8 Contenants le Dernières Années du Regne de Charles I, (The Hague 1725: de Rogissart), 289ff.
See at V, note KK: p. 583. This passage was dropped in 1759.
Note the irony involved. One of the main protagonists of the Common Law Sir Edward Coke believed that maintaining the ancient constitution was his first priority.

D. Hume, "Of the Origin of Government", Essays, 41

See also the change he made in his essay "Of the Liberty of the Press", Essays, 13, 604-605 In the editions of this essay between 1741 and 1768 he wrote that the liberty of press was essential to a free government. In the 1770 editions he excised this passage and in the 1777 edition it was replaced by the remark that the liberty of the press "is one of the evils, attending those mixt forms of government".
III, 322; more or less to Hume's amazement. Hume did not like this Harry and had a dim view of his achievements.
D. Hume, "Of the Coalition of Parties", Essays 498/499

"Of the Original Contract", (1748) Essays, 472; the quotation runs on: ", which gives liberty to the multitude, and makes the determination or choice of a new establishment depend upon a number, which nearly approaches to that of the body of the people: For it never comes entirely to the whole body of men." Clearly Hume feared such revolutionary events and given the experience of the French Revolution, let alone more recent ones, who can blame him? Evidently the American revolution was a special case, neither sympathizers, such as Hume, nor his friend William Robertson, who was against American independence, saw it as a threat to a total dissolution of government.

Hume argued his case with the aggression of an American district attorney and he argued largely from circumstantial evidence. See his note on the authenticity of the so-called Casket letters which Mary was supposed to have written to Bothwell. Hume had to admit that nobody had ever seen the originals. For once he was willing to relax his strict rule on authentic evidence, when it suited his purpose
V, 353. Those who regard Hume as a misogynist please note

A.C. Baier, A Progress of Sentiments, Reflections on Hume's Treatise, (Cambridge Mass. 1991: Harvard University Press), the quotation comes from A Treatise of Human Nature, P. H. Nidditch ed., (Oxford 1978: Clarendon Press) book II, Of the Passions, Section III, 415

It was consistent with Hume's revisionary labour in general that he eliminated a passage on the "most precipitant and most enormous" usurpation of parliament in collecting a militia without the concurrence of the king. (See at V, 379) It was the function of his revisions to change a discourse on rights into a discourse on political forces.

"England was for a long term in his debt for the only good and complete history one had of a country where one only wrote with a party spirit." Biographie Générale, (Paris 1862: Firmin Didot) vol.41/42, lemma "Rapin", 654
"To carry the royal authority farther than his father and his predecessors had done."

The Letters of David Hume, vol.1, letter 79, 5-1-1753, 170; apparently Hume, at that time, still accepted Rapin's version of Medieval and Tudor history.

ibidem, 253. "The only means for restoring calm and peace would be to leave the government on its old footing and the church in the state the Reformation had put it."

Anno 1717 Rapin had the following explanation of the enduring rivalries of tories and whigs after 1688. The rivalry according to him was religious, the whigs were low churchmen or dissenters and the tories high churchmen or catholics. Hume struggling with the distinctions between Court and Party on the one side and whig and tory on the other - see the variants he ultimately excised from his essay "Of the Parties of Great Britain" - must have felt that the religious factor was getting out of control, because the dissenters now belong to the Court and the advocates of the Church of England to the Country party. He ends his essay as follows: "This may convince us, that some biass still hangs upon our constitution, some extreme weight, which turns it from its natural course [please note the word "natural"] and causes a confusion of our parties." See Essays, 72

1773(2), 119.20/120.7: final version\~\**The following note is attached to the sentence which precedes this addition**: I, note: Sometimes the historians mention the people, populus, as a part of the parliament: But they always mean the laity, in opposition to the clergy. Sometimes, the word, communitas, is found; but it always means communitas baronagii. These points are clearly proved by Dr. Brady. [There is also mention sometimes made of a crowd or multitude that thronged into the great council on particular interesting occasions; but as deputies from boroughs are never once spoke of, the proof, that they had not then any existence, becomes the most certain and undeniable. These never could make a crowd, as they must have had a regular place assigned them, if they had made a regular part of the legislative body. There were only 130 boroughs who received writs of summons from Edward I.] It is expressly said in Gesta Reg. Steph. p. 932, that it was usual for the populace, vulgus, to crowd into the great councils; where they were plainly mere spectators, and could only gratify their curiosity.]]{Ia(1762), 409.23 note: Sometimes...Brady. [ ]}\~\ 1773(2), 119.20 note: Sometimes... Edward. [ ]

Hume was clearly influenced by Spelman's views on the Norman conquest and its impact on the constitutional development in England. That influence did not make him a tory, nor his acceptance of the idea of Saxon liberty a whig. On Spelman see J. Pocock, The Ancient Constitution, 91 ff.

The cheap and well-printed Liberty Classics edition has become a welcome contribution to Hume studies. There are, however, a number of infelicities and misprints in this edition which are listed here for the benefit of its readers.

The first one is the omission of "The History of Great Britain" as subtitle to volume 5. Hume made this the title for the set of volumes 6-8 in his 1770 edition so he must have attached some importance in keeping it in its place, even as subtitle. I will list a number of misprints as follows:

row.cell: **the passage** "calamity) invaded the last in so numerous a body, as seemed to"; **the passage should read**: "...when the Danes, encouraged by their successes against France as well as England (for both kingdoms were alike exposed to this dreadful calamity) invaded the last in so numerous a body, as seemed to threaten it with universal subjection."
In the margin: 11th October should be 14th October, see 1778(1), 191.
"earl of Locester" should be "earl of Glocester".
"these marks of dissidence" should be "these marks of diffidence".
"Hist. de Fretagne" should be "Hist. de Bretagne"
"a universal dissisence" should be "a universal diffidence".
"dissidence" should be "diffidence". The reader can be sure that where he reads "dissidence" in the History it should be "diffidence". Hume never uses "dissidence".
"a mutual dissidence" should be "a mutual diffidence".
"complaint" should be "complaints".**The correction in the LibertyClassic reprint can be justified, but all editions including 1778(5), note K line 1 have "complaints"..."was".
"object of their dissidence" should be "object of their diffidence"
"Scotish clergy" should be "Scottish clergy";**misprint also in the 1778 edition (1778(7), 69.23)**
The quotation should be closed with a -"-.

According to Sully James had the maxim that no prince in his first year should begin a considerable undertaking. Apparently the idea that he could regulate parliamentary elections was a sign of his ignorance not of his pretension. This note had almost reached its final form in Vb.

Some enlightened men such as Sir Francis Bacon and Sir Edwin Sandys wrote a remonstrance to insist on the dignity and authority of the Commons. They were in advance of their age and wrong in arguing that the Commons had ever received better treatment before. Except for a minor variant this version was reached in 1773. Petition of the Commons to the king to relax the laws in favour of the puritan showing a "violent animosity" towards the catholics at the same time. This addition is heavily edited in subsequent editions.

Hume adds to a long passage which until 1770 was part of the text the remark that he relegated the passage to a note to avoid "the style of dissertation" but that the views were important to justify a note. Indeed they are. The note contains Hume's view on the constitutional development of the English political system in a nutshell. In this time he maintains the division between court and country appeared as an expression of the more sophisticated and regular role of parliament in the system. The division at that time was religious. The established church being part of the Court party, the puritans of the country.

"The seeds of many a noble state have been sown in climates kept desolate by the wild manners of the antient inhabitants".

In this note in which Hume discusses the fate of the Stuarts of governing in a transitional period he takes out a remark on the use of these "digressions"to show partymen that certain measures are the necessary result of the situation.
The "severe sentence" against Prynne e.a. becomes "sentence".
An "arbitrary order of council" becomes an order of council.
Charles did not consider a judicious mixture of steadiness and facility in his policy.
The only hardship Mountnorris suffered was imprisonment during two days.
Argument of the Irishman Roger More that the time was ripe for a revolt of the Irish.
Every argument was used to make the king's administration odious and contemptible.
"Precipitant measure" of the king for raising troops becomes "measure".
Names (such as Cavaliers or Roundheads) can be enough reason to kill each other.

Elizabeth arrested a member in parliament and refused to justify her decision.

The most precipitant and enormous usurpation of parliament to collect a military force without the consent of the king.

The zealots insulted the scholars from Oxford. Excised was the last sentence: We are not told how the professors of Oxford answered this challenge.
Malignity of interpretation in the trial of Laud.
During no period human nature did wear so remarkable a form under the influence of religion.
Power of excommunication assumed by the sects as under the Druids.
Self-command of the king united with candor and sincerity.
General indignation of the royalists against the puritans who had robbed them of their possessions.
Hollis ascribes the tyranny of parliament to the Independents. Hume excised in 1762 the remark that if they had been less saintly they would have been less oppressive.
According to the king a presbyter not consecrated by a bishop could not perform communion or baptism. A fine point perhaps, but the king was supporting established religion.
"impious regicides" becomes "regicides".
The virtuous prince: "tho' perhaps not entirely innocent" was excised.

In his rewriting of the passage explaining why Cecil - responsible in part for the death of Mary Stuart and Essex - was favoured by James Hume puts more emphasis on the secret correspondence between Cecil and James.

In ordering a conference between the house and the judges James declared that he acted as an absolute king and that parliament derived its authority fron[[sic]] him. Originally Hume had written that Elizabeth had held the same opinion but that her prudence had restrained her from openly expressing it. In the new version it became: the reigning principle of her ministers "and the spring of all her administration".
On the treaty with Spain: In the rewriting Hume maintained that James had expressly reserved the right to assist the Dutch.

This is one of Hume's most important "anti-Whig" revisions. In his rewriting which in its substantive form was done in 1762 Hume emphasized that the preceding monarchs could expect unilaterally to alter the rates of customs. Now "a spirit of liberty" had taken possession of the House and they began to regulate their view more "by the future consequences" and aspired less "at maintaining the ancient constitution". (note the irony involved). Originally Hume had written: "The precedents for so dangerous an exercise of power were neither very recent or numerous." The duties of tonnage and poundage were usually levied by authority of parliament.
In a number of small rewritings Hume emphasized that the king's proclamations though inferior to laws were as yet uniform practice.

With a number of excisions and additions undertaken in 1759 and 1770 and reaching their final shape in 1773 Hume gave a more favourable view of James' sale of the cautionary towns to the Dutch. He curiously excised a passage in 1759 remarking of happy it was that Cromwell nor Charles II had no possession of them "to crush" the Dutch Republic.
Hume rewrote some small passages on the ceremonies James wanted to establish in Scotland.
His prerogative which he "greatly stretched" became "which he seems to have stretched".
Hume rewrote and added certain passages concerning James' subsidies to the Palatine explaining that James went beyond his narrow revenue to support his son in law.
In a note greatly shortened in its final version Hume rewrote a passage -softening his expression - that Elizabeth's reign was "not so perfect a model of liberty".
Quoting from Birch's Life of Prince Henry Hume added information on the prices of beef and mutton.
Originally Hume had written that the Commons had the honour of showing support to the Huguenots. This became misguided zeal.
About the appointment of Coke e.a. as sheriffs of the counties hoping to incapacitate them for the election to parliament.
An elaboration of the process by which encroachments on sovereign authority reduce it to becoming contemptible.
That his stubbornness and the fact that he was easy to influence "were the chief course of all his misfortunes" became "were in part the cause of his misfortunes".
The pretence of ancient precedents , the veil of which could "not possibly be thinner and more transparent" became: given its great authority "could not be wanting to him".
That religious tyranny might support civil tyranny became "religious might support civil authority".
Though the nation was treated like a conquered province became the king employed the whole extent of his prerogative.
The most invidious prerogative was exercised for the most invidious purpose became from a statement an argument of the enemies of the king.
A more submissive nation than the English would have shown "symptoms of discontent at these multiplied violences and disasters" became there was reason to fear some disorders or insurrection.
Whether the Commons would have stopped with their attempts at curtailing the prerogatives "may appear somewhat uncertain" became "may be much doubted".

This is a complicated set of revisions which is one of the most important instances where Hume changed his position concerning the legality of Charles' measures. The occasion is ship-money and the trial of Hambden. In 1754 Hume wrote that the imposition "is apparently the most avowed and most dangerous invasion of national privileges." This passage somewhat edited in subsequent editions was excised in 1778. In the meantime its impact was weakened by two notes introduced in 1759 - one taken out in 1770, another in 1778. In the first Hume remarked that Elizabeth at the time of the Armada ordered the harbours to fit out ships and in the second and longer note Hume argued that the King's apology for the imposition that necessity forced him to do so was weak and that particularly the judges were blameable in sustaining this argument. In his addition Hume then gave his final verdict that if the king was convinced that the defenseless condition of the kingdom necessitated this imposition he should have enforced it by the Starchamber as the instrument of his prerogative emphasizing the extraordinary character of the measure and not by an ordinary court. This set of revisions should be read against the backcloth of Hume's critical assessment of the imposition of ship-money.

Hume had written that Charles was apt to govern the church by an authority extending "beyond its proper bounds". This became : Charles believed this authority was inherent in the crown. Hume is using here an approach which can be observed elsewhere. A statement of fact became a psychological fact used to explain Charles' behaviour.

Charles "by his precipitations and oversights" had brought himself in a situation became in 1759 "by mistakes and oversights" and reads in the final version of 1773: "had fallen into such a situation".

The earl of Warwic and Lord Broke were searched for treasonable papers: Hume's orginal comment was: It is hard to say "whether the imprudence or illegality of these measures was most egregious". This became in 1759 these measures "were interpreted with some appearance of reason, to be invasions on the right of national assemblies.

Charles' transgressions of law were "palpable and obvious" became "sometimes" in 1759 and "in some few instances" in 1770. Hume was arguing that Charles has been judged more severely by historians than the Commons of which the transgressions were less obvious.
The expelling of members from the Commons who were monopolists was not entirely new. In the text Hume replaced the words
"unknown to all their predecessors" by "which had formerly been seldom practised" to indicate the presumption of authority by the Commons.
While the law "was openly violated" became "seemed to be violated in "many" (became: "several") instances.

Hume's original comment on the king's complaint that parliamentary committees undermined his authority was that there had never before "been occasion for severe remedies". This became: the commons "though themselves the greatest innovators", employed the usual artifice of complaining against innovations". Though the final formulation was reached in 1778, the major revision was made in 1759.

The news of the Irish rebellion was welcome to the Commons to promote their views (against church and monarchy). "Nothing" became "tended most to" as an expression of Hume's general tendency to soften his formulations.

Hume had written in 1754 that the creation of a formidable navy was an important security, but that preserving the harmony of government was even a greater public security. In 1759 he excised the passage and replaced it only in 1773 by a passage in which he emphasized that the fact that the king wanted to create a strong navy and not a strong army is "a sure proof, that he had formed no system for enslaving his people".

Hume added to the sentence that the Commons "by a bold and decisive stroke" had seized the power of the sword, that the Peers refused their concurrence to give a public warning "against the enterprises of papists and other ill-affected persons".

In this passage which was part of the text in 1754 and became a note since 1759 Hume altered a passage in which he originally argued that without philosophical scepticism it is impossible to counterfeit "holy fervors". This became that it is anyway impossible to counterfeit "holy fervors" (read "enthusiasm") because this kind of philosophical scepticism at the time, was unknown. A rare example of showing some understanding for the popular leaders against the king.

"Never did the nation possess more capacity, more courage, more public spirit, more disinterested zeal" became "Nevere were there individuals ... ". Hume dissociated himself from the idea that the parliamentarians represented the destiny of England.

This alteration is an interesting example of Fairfax "eminent for courage and for humanity" being guided not by "honor" or "by the nobler principle of virtue" but by disinterestedness being turned into something of a bigot who "strongly infected with prejudices or principles, derived from religious and party zeal" never was diverted from these principles by private interest or ambition.

Hume's original comment on Charles' distinction between "calling" them the parliament and "acknowledging" them by writing was, that he should have "kept at the widest difference from such refinements." This became that such a distinction is "common and familiar in all public transactions".

Except for a minor revision the passage was essentially rewritten in 1759 and is in tune with his major revision of note GG (see hereafter). Originally Hume wrote that the king wanted to promote the negotiation with the Irish rebels by sending Glamorgan. This became that he foresaw that Glamorgan had to make religious concessions to the rebels but he told him that he had to work together with Ormond, the lord lieutenant.

Originally Hume wrote that Ormond threw Glamorgan into prison when he heard of the treaty that Glamorgan had concluded with the rebels and that the king disowned him. To this day the king's veracity is called into question, Hume wrote. This became- essentially again in 1759 - that Ormond foreseeing the clamour against the king threw Glamorgan into prison, but the king telling parliament that Glamorgan only had the commision to raise forces in Ireland was not believed though "this declaration seems agreeable to the truth".

row.cell: This note was entirely rewritten in 1759 after Birch's treatise on the subject. In a subsequent editions only minor revisions occur. Originally Hume had argued on the supposition that Glamorgan's commission was forged. After reading Birch's treatise he followed a different line of argument to prove the king's innocence to the charge that he wanted to gain the support of Irish catholics against parliament. He now argued that Glamorgan in reaching an agreement had to act in close concert with Ormond. This way of argumentation, both in its original and rewritten form, is typical for Hume's argumentation. He assumes the maximum of rational calculation in the major players in the first place; secondly being convinced of the fact that Charles could not be capable of a major duplicity he reformulated his argument in such a way that he reached his goal on the basis of a different documentation even if he had to make the concession to the critics of the king that Glamorgan had a commission to deal with the rebels.

cell.emph: Bill against immodest dress of women did not pass.
The earl of Derby summoned to surrender the isle of Man sent an indignant refusal to Ireton.
Hume added an explanation of the name "Damn'd Barebone".
Prince of the Palatine restored to part of his dominions had chosen the side of parliament against his uncle.
Anecdote about Cromwell's blasphemous pleasantry.
About Dorcas Earberry making an oath that she had been ressurrected from the death.
About the low revenue of the king between 1637 and 1640.
The monopolies of the exclusive companies were ignored during the Commonwealth.
About revenues and the introduction of tea etc..
About the selling of the king's "curiosities".
Harvey suffered because of his "doctrine of the circulation of blood". So slow is the progress of truth.
Small standing army of Charles II seen by Mordaunt as a considerable force.
James mentions Venner's insurrection as a reason for keeping these guards.
Added was the remark that Clarendon in his Memoirs said he was never opposed to or promoted the Portuguese match.
About the queen's portion.
Kings zeal for popery went further than is here supposed as appears from James II' Memoirs. One of the revisions made after Hume's discovery of these Memoirs in Paris in 1763.
Sale of Dunkirk cannot be charged on Clarendon but on the over-frugal maxims of parliament.
The dark counsels of the cabal together with some catholic courtiers.
Gourville says that Charles II was never sincere about the Triple Alliance harbouring a violent animosity against de Wit.
In memoriam of Monk and an account of his great services to his native country by restoring the monarchy.
In memoriam of Fairfax who "allowed himself to be carried into many criminal enterprizes, with the best and most upright intentions". See V, 488
To Charles' intention to enlarge his authority Hume added "and altering the national religion". An example of a revision based on his discovery in Paris.
Added: the people of which Charles entertained a great diffidence.
Attachment to France aided by money from Paris. See Hume's discovery in 1763.
Henry Cromwell died after a peaceful life.
Hume adds Dalrymple's discovery that the king had signed a secret treaty with France "one of the most dishonourable and most scandalous acts, that ever proceeded from a throne".
It appears that Charles secretly received a sum from Lewis of two million livres. See Hume's discovery of 1763 and Dalrymple's supplement.
Hume cites from Dalrymple's Supplement on bribes received from France by English men of note, among them Algernon Sidney.
Pretension that the House of Commons could appoint its own Speaker was "somewhat new".
Given the low state of public revenue and military power it may be asked whether "still ... some discretionary authority in the crown" was not necessary.
Buckingham to the king: Is Ormond out of favour with you or you with him?
Halifax was considered an intriguer. Hume added: "with reason".
Prince Rupert died. He was suspected of favouring the country party.
It appears from Dalrymple's Appendix that Charles received a million livres next to his usual pension for his connivance at the seizure of Luxembourg.
Terms under which Charles received a subsidy from Lewis one of which is that Charles promises to disengage himself gradually from his alliance with Spain, communicated to Hume while in Paris.
James II' Memoirs confirm the rumour that Charles II considered a change of course and curry the favour of his subjects.
Hume adds to Rockingham's remark that the king never said a foolish thing nor did a wise one Charles' remark that his discourse was his own "his actions were the ministry's".
Remarkable that the convention for the Declaration of Rights did not condemn the dispensing power of the king in general.
Death of the grandfather of the young duke of Ormond in 1688.
Indeed if parliament had been willing to grant sufficient revenues to Charles I and II "all disorders in both reigns might easily have been prevented".
Miscellaneous economic facts.
Sums of money which could be transmitted to Hamburg and Munster surprisingly small.
Not until 1694 there was a tolerable liberty of the press.
"Such perpetual terrors hang over tyranny and injustice!" Comment on Parliament.
About thirty Irish prisoners of war sold as slaves to the Barbados.
Owen Oneale submitted at discretion.
The captured Montrose and his heroic mind.
"The corruptions of the best things produce the worst": on the cant of the covenanters.
Wilmot in disguise in the company of the later Charles II.
One Pope recognized Charles and fell on his knees.
It was not seen that the enthusiastic spirit raised to such height was "to elude all the tyes of civil and moral duty".
"Pretended" was excised from "Pretended saints" of congregations.
The thin pretext under which the assembly voted themselves a parliament, the nation was reduced to great subjection.
This parliament in the greater part consisted of the dregs of the human species.
Blake told seamen to despise castles at land.
The marques Medina Celi perished in the flames: Such events which melt the tender heart are matter of triumph in the barbarous trade of war.
Blake, dying, back to England which he passionately loved.
Cromwell's expenses for intelligence.
Sexby with his plot against Cromwell would have been considered a hero in Rome; "our sentiments, with regard to tyrannicide at least, certainly contribute more to the interest of civil society."

In comment on Richard Cromwell: how unhappy is the high regard for talent even when misapplied. "The love of popular applause is rendered an additional incitement to ambition ,usurpation, and civil disorder."
Seven hundred thousand pounds a year of bullion were coined in the English mint.
Inigo Jones as architect never surpassed.
Laws, a musician, killed at the siege of Chester.
Lack of generosity of Charles to Ben Johnson and his reaction.
Bill about compensation to the king for abolition of wardships and purveyances. Though there was a need for the abolition of these "Gothic institutions" the way of purchasing them was perhaps unjust.
About the revenue of the king between 1637 and 1640. Hume had added the same remark as a note in 1770. (see VI, 146 note)
The covenant in Scotland was declared unlawful: "a violent shock to the bigotted prejudices of the nation".
Debate about the oaths exacted from magistrates and Southampton's objections in the House of Lords. Hume's comment on the extremism of victorious parties.
Objections of the chancellor (Clarendon) and Ormond against the Portuguese match.
Lambert died a Roman catholic.
In his appraisal of Lord Ashley Hume left out the words "Restless, turbulent, factious".

"No particular articles seem here to have been signed" between Charles and Lewis. This passage had to be taken out because of his discovery in Paris of such a treaty. (Hume did do so in 1770 not in CAN (1766)!) Hume added in 1770: "the change of religion in England".

Charles much have seen the function of the dutchess of Orleans but he was too much the slave of pleasure to take measures against her influence. This excisions again much be a result of his discovery in Paris in which it became clear that Charles was actively involved in this alliance.
What a dishonour that the king was so little trusted in Holland while Temple, whom he recalled, had the confidence of the Dutch.
Bridgeman, though not admitted to the secrets of the Cabal, should not have covered their conceit.
Princes revering catholicism as sacred could not be have a sincere affection for the people with its horror for popery. A revision on the basis of his discovery of 1763.
Charles could not have proposed the utter destruction of the Dutch republic, but he wanted part of the booty. This was an excision on the basis of the 1763 discovery.

The translation of Horace's Ode was signed Blacklocke in the final version and was unsigned in the first edition in 1759. Hume added an advertisment for Blacklock's "elegant collection of poems" which have their own merit but which are "very extraordinary, when we consider what form of imagination is there displayed by an author born blind".
Suppression of coffee-houses for which the English retained "a mighty fondness".
Sorrow at the French court for death of Turenne.
Anecdote of William III at the battle of St. Omers.
"Scandalous" excised from "scandalous practice" of giving bribes to parliamentarians of the court party. See Hume's notion of the necessity of corruption!
No one will give up the dominance over men's minds. About the restored authority of the bishops.
Lauderdale's mismanagement of Scotland.
Twelve Scottish gentlemen were deprived of their houses, an act even "tyrannical" in Asia.
All royalists, though lovers of liberty through the spirit of faction were willing to give the king uncontrolled influence in all corporations.
The jury against Sidney was not composed of freeholders, an irregularity and great reproach on the administration.
When the suspending power had negative effects people questioned the legality. Excised was: "as they had good reason".
Criticism of sects in a certain historical period even if they now have become moderate in their views is no proof of irreligion.
Few civilized states punish frustrated intention with severity became: intentions though they never appeared in any overt act against the state.
Montrose's "magnanimous disposition" became "daring character"
A reformulation of a passage on the encounter between the English and the Dutch fleet.
Protector could observe how unpopular his government was, became: the prejudices maintained against his government.
A tenth penny imposed on royalists, "so oppressive and iniquous (1759:"iniquitous")" became an imposition "which commonly passed by the name of decimation".
"The King's subjects" became the "British malcontents".
In the case of Blake: His errors he shared with the multitudes, his virtues were his own, became: an almost perfect character the least stained with predominant "errors and violences".
James Naylor "pretended to raise" became: "He raised" (from the death).
Wards and liveries as being a "grievances by all lovers of liberty" became "as a grievous burthen by the nobility and the gentry".
Parliament assigned not any funds became: "scarcely assigned any funds".
Parliament "was reduced to such a state of servile complaisance" in passing sentence on Argyle , became: "scrupled not to pass sentence".
The bill of uniformity was the triumph of prelacy over presbyterianism. This became: the bill of uniformity was a pledge to episcopal hierarchy and of their antipathy to presbyterianism.
In the first version Brounker's impunity is accounted for by the protection of the king's mistress. In 1766 Hume quotes a different story from James II's Memoirs.
"Allured by the prospect of gain" Charles did not prepare his navy. This became "moved by an ill-timed frugality".
King appointed a kind of high-commission court became "the privy-council"...
King's resolution was only fixed after a visit by his sister. This became: visit of dutchess of Orleans was basis of still stronger suspicions.
Charles in his war against the Dutch driven by "heroism", this became "patriotism"? (Hume answers this question in the negative, Charles was after the liberties of the English.

Originally Hume had written that no treaty had existed between the two kings and they were more guided by events than by a concerted plan and that it was improbable that Charles would have agreed to a division of the Dutch republic. In 1766 Hume relates, on the basis of James II's Memoirs, that there was such a conspiracy. Objects were a change of religion in England and a division of the Dutch republic. Implied was the installation of absolute kingship in England. In the edition of 1778 Hume quoted Dalrymple to the extent that there was a secret treaty (only known to his catholic advisers and kept from Buckingham, Lauderdale and Shaftesbury) and a sham treaty. "One cannot sufficiently admire the absolute want of common sense which appears throughout the whole of this criminal transaction."
Arlington and Danby the chief ministers became: "possessed chiefly the king's confidence".
Prince of Orange was surprised to observe, became: he could not regard without contempt.
Charles passed the greater part of his later life because of the charms of his easy life with his mistresses; originally he also wrote because of passion or appetite of pleasure.
Coleman lately secretary to duchess of York eventually became secretary to the late duchess of York.

Originally Hume wrote that the choice of the Speaker is with the House alone which may be regarded as an acquisition by parliament. This became choice lies with the House but the king retains the power to reject the candidate.
Nobody could doubt that the king wanted to rule Scotland by fear became: It is said with some authority that the king was displeased with these cruelties.

Originally Hume wrote that the Commons were contented to grant a large supply to James II and rivet their own chains upon them. This became: assembly instead of guarding their liberties made the king independent and increased their dangers.
Herbert, chief justice "fell under a great load of infamy" became: "was exposed to a great and general reproach.

Originally Hume wrote that no remedy was provided for the dispensing power of the king, parties being for or against it. This became: in the past this prerogative had coexisted with some degree of liberty in the subject, but it could not be made compatible "with those accurate and regular limitation, which had of late been established".
"Head-long" and "imperious" James deemed the law which forbid a court of high commission no obstacle. Hume dropped "head-long" and "imperious" in the final version.
James' regime was supported by precedents "both modern and doubtful". This became: "supported by many strong precedents in the history of England".
In original version Sunderland was loyal to the king. In the final version it is considered probable that he entered in correspondence with prince William.
"Bad" administration became "exceptionable" administration.
The Whigs more noble "undoubtedly", this became "perhaps" in their ends.
In 1770 Hume wrote about despicable compositions such as of Rapin Thoyras, in 1778 Locke, Sidney and Hoadly were added to the list.

The ruling party has assumed the right to represented the other party as governed by the lowest prejudices. This became: The Whigs are forgetting that a love of liberty "ought commonly to be subordinate to a reverence for established government".

note.p: Final versions are marked in bold type. Variants marked with [W] are used in the discussion of Hume's so-called anti-Whig revisions. Only editions with revisions are marked in this list. Those marked with a reference to a certain edition (mostly Va) in the main follow that edition. Those without a reference follow the final version. 1763 is left out, because it contains no major revisions.

div.p: **In this appendix I have tried(!) to note down all the variants between editions in I, chapter 45. To distinguish these variants from the one given in my selective version I have marked them with 〈〈〈 〉〉〉 for alterations, and [[ ]] for additions and excisions. In this version I have also included Vd(1763) in my collation. I have searched the text on the words, "king", "princess",(so that the reader can be reasonably sure that the word occurring without a first capital letter is not an oversight, but a fact), "favour", "vigour", "labour", "honour", "fervour", "knowledge", "though", "through", "between", "Scottish","throughout", "knowledge", "ancient", "pretence", and "endeavour".
The most important conclusion, as mentioned in the Preface, is that Hume indeed "teleologically" worked towards the perfection of his text. Other conclusions are:

1. Apparently Hume used capitals to indicate the king or princess as person and not as institution ( when he used lower case) or to emphasize a certain word. The capitals were dropped in 1773(6), chapter 45 (except in the table of contents). Before that edition the use of capitals is by no means consistent. Hume himself kept on using capitals in his correspondence.

2. Hume changed the spelling of 〈〈〈labor〉〉〉 rigorously into 〈〈〈labour〉〉〉 etc.; Hume wrote to Millar on 20 June 1758 about "the New Method of Spelling" according to which "honor" should be preferred to "honour" and he recommends the new method to Strahan for his History. In fact the new spelling was only used in Va(1754). Beauchamp tells that by late 1759 Hume had rejected the new spelling. That should be early 1759, because IIIa, IVa, Vb and VIb were published in February of that year.

3. In the same radical fashion he changed "betwixt" into "between". Given his dislike of the 1763 edition it is ironic that "betwixt" came back in the title page of 1763(5), chapter 46 and stayed there since.
4. "Acknowlege" became "acknowledge" (and "knowlege" "knowledge") in 1770(6) and 1778(6). Hume, in his correspondence, switched from "acknowlege" to "acknowledge" in his later letters.
5. "tho'" and "thro'" changed to "though" and "through" in 1770(6) except for two cases of oversight which were corrected in 1773(6).
6. It seems to be a regular pattern that Hume changed "where" into "in which".

7. In 1758 Hume wrote Horace Walpole that he had been "seduc'd by the example of all the best historians even among the moderns, such as Matchiavel, Fra Paolo, Davila, Bentivoglio" to present few references, but he assured Walpole that in the new volume he is preparing on the Tudors he has been "been very careful to obviate this objection." As far as V, chapter 45 is concerned the reader had to wait till 1762.**
